docs.lead_paragraph: FROM time to time, Philips Electronics has used its ''sense and simplicity'' campaign to clear away marketing that bothers consumers. Last year it paid Hearst $2 million to remove the subscription cards from four of its magazines for a month, and several times it has bought up blocks of commercials on television shows and used them to give air time back to the programmers (like CBS's ''60 Minutes'' and NBC's evening news). Now Philips is using the same campaign to showcase a free service it is offering to cellphone users. The service, Philips Simplicity Concierge, lets people send text messages to seek information about popular destinations in major cities -- restaurants in Boston, for instance, or spas in London -- and get a Yellow Pages-style listing of five options, including phone numbers for making reservations.

headline.main: Product Tips You Can Use, by Way of Cellphone

At least three brokerage houses -- Citigroup, Cowen & Company and Piper Jaffray -- raised their ratings on Amazon, the largest online bookseller and increasingly a Web vendor of other products. At least five increased their target prices for the stock. In trading yesterday, Amazon closed up $12.06 at $56.81, its highest closing price in more than three years.

It cited improving margins in its core retail business and increased sales in categories like electronics and soft goods, including jewelry, apparel and shoes.

docs.lead_paragraph: FORD SEES A FUTURE -- Ford Motor Company executives said that a smaller loss in the first quarter was proof that their corporate overhaul was working. [Page C1.] LOOKING FOR A BIG HIT -- Perella Weinberg Partners may be just a year and a half old as an investment bank, but can it deliver the headline-grabbing, blockbuster mergers that made a name for its founder, Joseph R. Perella? [C1.] SOLD ON EBAY, SHIPPED VIA AMAZON -- Amazon.com is expanding a program that allows independent sellers -- even vendors who sell through Amazon's e-commerce rival, eBay -- to use its network of distribution centers to store and ship their products. [C1.] A NEW KIND OF BUYOUT -- An $8 billion bid by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Goldman Sachs for Harman International Industries, the maker of JBL speakers, has a potentially groundbreaking twist: The buyers have offered Harman shareholders a chance to retain a stake in the company, and share in any profit made if the company is later sold or taken public again. [C1.] STRONG QUARTER FOR MICROSOFT -- Microsoft reported quarterly sales and profits that surpassed Wall Street's expectations, suggesting that early sales of its new Windows Vista operating system were off to a solid start. [C3.] RISING PROFIT AT EXXON MOBIL -- Exxon Mobil reported another surge in profits for the first quarter of the year because of stronger earnings from its refining, marketing and chemicals businesses. The results -- Exxon said they were its best ever for any first quarter -- were particularly noteworthy given the mixed earnings picture reported in recent days by other large oil companies. [C4.] BETTER CHANCES FOR TRADE BILL -- Prospects have suddenly improved for bipartisan agreement on trade legislation in Congress, thanks in part to a talk between President Bush and Representative Charles B. Rangel, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. [C3.] BRISTOL CHOOSES INTERIM CHIEF -- After an eight-month search for a new chief executive, the drug maker Bristol-Myers said it would go with the interim chief, James M. Cornelius. [C2.] PUBLIC CONCERNED OVER WARMING -- Americans in large bipartisan numbers say the heating of the earth's atmosphere is having serious effects on the environment now or will soon and think that it is necessary to take immediate steps to reduce its effects, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. [A20.] EMI'S NORTH AMERICAN UNIT -- EMI Group, the struggling British music giant, has hired the longtime industry executive Roger Ames, a former chairman of Warner Music Group, to revive its North American operation. The appointment of Mr. Ames, left, comes more than three months after a management shake-up in which EMI ousted the two senior executives overseeing its recorded music operation. [C7.] A MODEL OF CONSISTENCY, ONCE -- For 25 years, Absolut vodka ran a humorous campaign celebrating its distinctive bottle, and became renowned for the consistency of its pitches to consumers. Now the brand is changing advertising approaches for the second time in 15 months. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C3.] MORE SUSPECTED BRIBES AT SIEMENS -- A day after the chief executive of Siemens announced he would step down, the company warned that it expected to report a ''significant increase'' in the number of possible bribes identified in an internal investigation. [C7.] MYSPACE.COM HEADING TO CHINA -- Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is taking MySpace.com to China, a latecomer to China's crowded field of online social networking sites that is betting it can overcome that handicap by competing unconventionally as a start-up. [C7.] CANADIAN RULES ON EMISSIONS -- Canadian industries must cut the rate at which they produce gases linked to global warming by 18 percent over the next three years, the federal government said. [C7.] PROFIT NEWS HAS LITTLE IMPACT -- Stocks ended mixed as strong profit reports from companies like Apple Inc. and 3M failed to galvanize Wall Street. Still, a modest advance gave the Dow Jones industrial average another record close. [C9.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. The US Airways Group reported that profit edged up 2 percent in the first quarter on modest revenue growth, and repeated its forecast for a profitable year. (AP) The health insurer Aetna reported an 8 percent increase in first-quarter profits, pointing to membership growth as proof that consumer marketing applied to health insurance is working. (AP) The 3M Company, considered a bellwether for the economy, posted a far better-than-expected quarterly profit, sending its shares up. (REUTERS) Coca-Cola Enterprises reported a 6 percent decline in earnings but beat Wall Street estimates, helped by the introduction of Coke Zero in Europe and raw material costs that rose less than expected. (REUTERS) The Belo Corporation, publisher of The Dallas Morning News, reported a drop in quarterly profit and revenue because of decreasing sales of classified and other advertising. (REUTERS)

docs.lead_paragraph: TRAVEL to Latin America has been on the upswing as countries there look to tourism for economic growth, and tour operators in the United States and Canada offer exotic vacations to the south. But until recently, getting around within Latin America -- even in popular countries like Mexico -- was a hassle often involving multiple plane changes or long bus rides over rough roads. Now, thanks to an increase in low-cost airlines in Brazil and Mexico, which account for 60 percent of the Latin America's air traffic, it's getting easier to jet around.

headline.main: Travel in Latin America: Cheaper and Easier

docs.lead_paragraph: American air safety investigators on Wednesday attributed a disastrous collision over the Amazon last year partly to cockpit systems' failure to alert the crew of a business jet that its anti-collision equipment had failed. The accident, on Sept. 29, killed all 154 people aboard a Boeing 737 operated by a Brazilian carrier, Gol Linhas Aéreas Inteligentes. The smaller plane made an emergency landing, its two pilots and five passengers unharmed.

headline.main: Air Disaster Is Linked to Failure of Safety System

docs.lead_paragraph: EVERYMAN, by Philip Roth. (Vintage International, $13.) A nameless protagonist grapples with aging, physical decline and impending death in this slender, elegant novel. Roth begins with Everyman's end: the novel opens at his funeral, and goes back in time as he ponders his middle-class New Jersey boyhood, his successful advertising career on Madison Avenue, his three failed marriages and a series of increasingly frequent health crises. ''Everyman'' won the 2007 PEN/Faulkner award for fiction. ''Roth takes the writer's free acknowledgment of many literary modes,'' Nadine Gordimer wrote in the Book Review, ''while unceasingly experimenting with his own.'' IRAN AWAKENING: One Woman's Journey to Reclaim Her Life and Country, by Shirin Ebadi with Azadeh Moaveni. (Random House, $14.95.) Ebadi, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2003, was stripped of her judgeship when the Islamic revolution overthrew the shah in 1979. ''I was a woman, and this revolution's victory demanded my defeat,'' Ebadi writes in this memoir, which describes her tireless efforts as a lawyer and human rights activist. THE DOCTOR'S DAUGHTER, by Hilma Wolitzer. (Ballantine, $13.95.) After 12 years of silence, Wolitzer wrote this fast-paced family drama about Alice Brill, a 51-year-old wife, mother and frustrated writer. As her marriage languishes and her once-authoritative father sinks into dementia, Alice is forced to confront the illusions she has created about herself and her family. RESTLESS GIANT: The United States From Watergate to Bush v. Gore, by James T. Patterson. (Oxford University, $18.95.) This is an impressive history -- social, economic and political -- of late-20th-century America, from Richard Nixon's departure from the White House and America's departure from Vietnam to the bitter partisanship of Bill Clinton's impeachment and Bush v. Gore. Picking up where his previous volume, ''Grand Expectations: The United States, 1945-1974,'' left off, Patterson traces the collapse of the Soviet Union, the ''culture wars,'' the national debate over abortion and the Republican takeover of Washington. ''This is first-rate history by a first-rate historian,'' our reviewer, Charles Peters, wrote. A LAND OF GHOSTS: The Braided Lives of People and the Forest in Far Western Amazonia, by David G. Campbell. (Rutgers University, $18.95.) Over the last 30 years, Campbell has been conducting ecological studies in the Amazon, ''the last continent-sized stretch of untrammeled wilderness on earth.'' In ''A Land of Ghosts'' he takes readers on an odyssey upriver, mapping the plant species and exploring what he calls ''one of the great and enduring conundrums of nature'': how the Amazon's many species have evolved, and how they coexist. COME TOGETHER, FALL APART: A Novella and Stories, by Cristina HenrÃquez. (Riverhead, $14.) HenrÃquez's first collection provides intense close-ups of young Panamanians whose lives are in enormous flux. One story, ''Ashes,'' follows the unraveling effects of a mother's sudden death on her daughter. A DEATH IN BELMONT, by Sebastian Junger. (Harper Perennial, $14.95.) Junger, the author of ''The Perfect Storm,'' explores a brutal strangling that took place in his hometown, Belmont, Mass., in 1963, and asks whether the man convicted of the crime -- a black day laborer -- was, in fact, innocent and whether Albert DeSalvo, the self-confessed Boston Strangler, could have committed the crime instead. (DeSalvo worked for Junger's parents for several months during 1962 and 1963, and was at their home the day of the murder.) JOSEPH SMITH: Rough Stone Rolling, by Richard Lyman Bushman with the assistance of Jed Woodworth. (Vintage, $18.95.) In 1827 Joseph Smith, a barely literate 21-year-old, discovered a set of golden plates in rural upstate New York, whose unfamiliar characters he translated into the 584-page Book of Mormon. Bushman, an emeritus professor of history at Columbia and a practicing Mormon, carefully balances reverence and objectivity as he recounts how Smith went on to organize a church, found cities and attract thousands of followers before his assassination in 1844. ''Once the reader despairs of ever finding out whether Smith was God's own spokesman or the L. Ron Hubbard of his day, it's possible to enjoy a tale that's as colorful, suspenseful and unlikely as any in American history,'' Walter Kirn wrote here. WHITEMAN, by Tony D'Souza. (Harvest/Harcourt, $13.) In D'Souza's intensely observed first novel, Jack Diaz, a 20-something from Chicago, recalls his hapless years as a relief worker in coup-ridden Ivory Coast, where he discovered ways of coping with cultural dislocation and changed the world very little. Ihsan Taylor

docs.lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s, when Pope John Paul II wanted to clamp down on what he considered a dangerous, Marxist-inspired movement in the Roman Catholic Church, liberation theology, he turned to a trusted aide: Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger. Now Cardinal Ratzinger is Pope Benedict XVI, and when he arrives here on Wednesday for his first pastoral visit to Latin America he may be surprised at what he finds. Liberation theology, which he once called ''a fundamental threat to the faith of the church,'' persists as an active, even defiant force in Latin America, home to nearly half the world's one billion Roman Catholics.

headline.main: As Pope Benedict Heads to Brazil, Rival Theology Retains Its Appeal

docs.abstract: Pope Benedict XVI will make his first pastoral visit to Brazil, where liberation theology that he once called 'threat to the faith of the church' persists as active, even defiant force; over past 25 years, as movement sought to mix politics and religion, Vatican moved to silence clerical theorists of liberation theology; social and economic ills movement highlighted have worsened and politics of region have also drifted leftward, giving new impetus and credibility to movement's demand that church embrace 'preferential option for the poor'; in Brazil, world's most populous Roman Catholic nation, there are 80,000 'base communities,' grass-roots building blocks of liberation theology; 'Bible circles' meet to read and discuss scripture from viewpoint of theology of liberation; during Pope's five-day visit he will meet with Pres Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, canonize a saint, preach to the faithful and visit drug treatment center, then address opening session of conference of Latin American bishops that will discuss future of church; some liberation theology supporters will be present; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Liberation theology, which the pope once called “a fundamental threat,” retains its appeal in Latin America.

docs.lead_paragraph: China Doll Of the great American filmmakers, few are as poorly represented on home video as Frank Borzage, the grand master of Hollywood romance whose films Andrew Sarris once described as shot through with ''a genuine concern with the wondrous inner life of lovers in the midst of adversity.'' Mr. Borzage had the bad luck to make several of his most important films for Fox, including the transcendently beautiful ''7th Heaven'' (1927), which won three Academy Awards (for best director of a dramatic picture, best actress and best adapted screenplay).

docs.lead_paragraph: Pardon my modest blush while I do something here that may appear uncomfortably self-serving. A recurrent theme in your replies to these columns has been how much people miss my old show(s) and how they wish they could see them now. A recent commenter confessed to a life-long "crush" on Katharine Hepburn and just learned that I did two full shows with her on my ABC late-night show. Another writer, Hepburn-smitten, would "give anything" to see them. You, sir (as I recall), can give considerably less than that. And you could probably see them today. Another writer suggested that DVDs of the shows would be a good idea. I don't know which of us should be embarrassed but DVDs are already out here.

docs.lead_paragraph: 'ANYTHING GOES' (Tonight through Sunday) These days, anything goes, and that includes very young actors performing Cole Porter. This production is by the Pied Piper Children's Theater of NYC. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m. and Sunday at 4 p.m., Holy Trinity Church, 20 Cumming Street, near Broadway, Inwood, (212) 544-2976; $10; $7 for under 16 and 65+. 'BUG BOY BLUES' (Tomorrow and Sunday) Kafka for kids? That's roughly the idea behind this show by Lisa Railsback, which explores the mind of young Gregor Samsa, subject of ''The Metamorphosis.'' (Through June 3.) Tomorrow at noon and 2 p.m., Sunday at 2 and 4 p.m., the Looking Glass Theater, 422 West 57th Street, Clinton, (212) 352-3101; $12; $10 for 12 and under. 'DANCE MAKERS & GROUND BREAKERS' (Tomorrow) Both these artistic categories are represented by children in this celebratory evening, which showcases the creativity of 80 students who have spent the last nine months in choreography workshops at Loco-Motion Dance Theater for Children. At 7 p.m., the Miller Theater, Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights, loco-motiondancetheatre.org; $10. 'EBONY BLACK' (Tomorrow) Though based on ''Snow White,'' this new musical isn't at all like the fairy tale or the Disney version: for one thing, the heroine isn't white. Produced by NY Artists Unlimited and Montauk Theater Productions/Shooting Star Theater, it centers on a dark-skinned young woman who is mistakenly sent to a cold, rich Hamptons matron seeking a daughter. (Through May 26.) At the Seaport District Cultural Association Performing Space, southwest corner of Beekman and Front Streets, Lower Manhattan, (212) 242-6036, NYartists.org; $10; $5 for under 12. Reservations advised. 'HOOFERS ON PARADE' (Tonight through Sunday) Busby Berkeley's 1930s films were the inspiration for this musical, an exuberant collaboration between the youth troupe Downtown Art and the Nature Theater of Oklahoma. Expect lots of toe-tapping. (Through May 20.) Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Sunday at 2 p.m., Downtown Art, 61 East Fourth Street, sixth floor, East Village, (212) 479-0885; $8; $5 for students. 'THE SANDWICH KID: A FILM ABOUT SIBLINGS AND DISABILITIES' (Tuesday) The JCC in Manhattan will present this documentary in which Jace King, 12, interviews children about living with siblings who have disabilities. The film is also a personal odyssey for Jace and his mother, Keri Bowers, the producer: Jace's older brother, Taylor, has high-functioning autism. At the screening the JCC will show artwork by Justin Canha, a 17-year-old with autism. At 8 p.m., 334 Amsterdam Avenue, at 76th Street, (646) 505-5708, jccmanhattan.org; $25; $20 for members. MARIA SANGIOLO (Sunday) Folk singers are often associated with the 1960s generation, but this one is firmly devoted to today's young. Ms. Sangiolo will entertain children 3 and up with an interactive concert at the Jewish Museum. At 2 p.m., 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3337, thejewishmuseum.org. Tickets: $15; $10 for under 12; $12 and $8 for family-level members. SKATE FOR HEALTH DAY (Tomorrow) Rollerblade, in conjunction with more than a dozen skating schools across the country, is offering free group in-line skating lessons; no charge for equipment. The Central Park Skate School is taking part. Information and registration (required): freeskatelesson.com. 'SPRANG THANG' (Tonight through Sunday) Ma Rainey, Bessie Smith, Billie Holiday and Dinah Washington will be reincarnated by teenagers in this new musical by Goldee Greene, performed by the students of the Amas Musical Theater's Rosetta Lenoire Musical Theater Academy. (Through May 20.) Tonight at 7:30, tomorrow at 3 and 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., the Players Theater, 115 Macdougal Street, at West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 352-3101; $20; $13 for students and 65+. 'STEP RIGHT UP!' (Tomorrow and Sunday, Tuesday through Thursday) ''Above the boardwalk'' might be the subtitle for this edition of the Big Apple Circus, which recreates an amusement park by the sea. (Through May 28.) Tomorrow and Sunday at 12:30 and 4:30 p.m.; Tuesday and Wednesday at 11 a.m.; Thursday at 11 a.m. and 6:30 p.m. Cunningham Park, Francis Lewis Boulevard and Union Turnpike, Hollis Hills, Queens, (212) 307-4100; $14 to $37. 'TAINAH -- AN AMAZON ADVENTURE' (Tomorrow and Sunday) The New York International Children's Film Festival presents this Brazilian movie about Tainah, an 8-year-old orphan who must find a way to stop a group of poachers in the Amazon rain forest. (In English, for ages 5 to 10.) At 11 a.m., 323 Avenue of the Americas, at West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 349-0330, gkids.com; $10.75; $7 for children and 65+. TEACH YOUR CHILD TO RIDE A BIKE (Tomorrow) This two-hour workshop, sponsored by the Parks and Recreation Department and the organization Bike New York, promises to eliminate both skinned knees and frayed nerves. To be held in a variety of locations in the five boroughs (it will be repeated on May 19 and Memorial Day), from 10 a.m. to noon, the class will teach children how to balance and how to start, stop and steer. Participants must have their own helmets and bicycles. Free, but preregistration required: BikeNewYork.org/safety--ed/classes/teach--child.html. YOUTH TRACK & FIELD & WELLNESS JAMBOREE (Tomorrow) Young athletes can show their stuff in this competition, from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., sponsored by the New York Road Runners Foundation and Mount Sinai Medical Center. Events for ages 4 to 10 are in the morning; those for 11 to 15 are in the afternoon. Everyone takes home a ribbon and a T-shirt. A fair will offer free health tests. At the Icahn Stadium, Randalls Island, (212) 423-2227, nyrrfoundation.org.; free.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a major speech on Sunday, Pope Benedict XVI condemned capitalism and Marxism as ''systems that marginalize God'' and urged the Latin American clergy to feed people's spiritual hunger as the way to ease poverty and halt the Roman Catholic Church's steady decline in the region. Speaking to Latin American bishops here for a conference on the church's direction for the next decade, the pope also condemned abortion and contraception and laws that permit them. Such laws, he said, are ''threatening the future of peoples.''

docs.lead_paragraph: EARNING 22 percent on your investments while holding half of your portfolio in cash is no easy trick, but last year Seth A. Klarman pulled it off, and it was not the first time. Mr. Klarman, a 49-year-old hedge fund manager, has turned in market-beating performances since 1983, while perpetually warning that the markets were dangerous and that investors should minimize risk.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT seems that a one-week trip to the shore, with days spent digging for clams and nights spent camping under the stars, has long ago ceased to be enough of a diversion for families planning their summer getaways. Now, the options range from cooking lessons in Italy (with even toddlers getting some kitchen time) to marionette-making courses in Prague to ''volunteer vacations'' that include trips to orphanages in China. ''Family travel continues to grow as more and more parents, particularly those working full time, view vacations as a way to 'reunite' the family, more than an occasion for rest and relaxation,'' said Peter Yesawich, chief executive of Yesawich, Pepperdine, Brown & Russell, a travel marketing firm. According to the 2007 National Leisure Travel Monitor, a yearly report by the company, family travel will be up this summer, as nearly 40 percent of adults plan to take a vacation with children, up from 32 percent five years ago.

headline.main: The Family Vacation, Reinvented

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Shana Kelly, a literary agent at the William Morris Agency, submitted Curtis Sittenfeld's first novel, ''Cipher,'' to book publishers in 2003, she had high expectations. She contacted nearly two dozen high-ranking editors at major publishers, expecting every one to make offers for her client's coming-of-age story set at a boarding school. Within weeks, though, most editors had passed. ''They loved it but weren't sure they could sell a lot of copies, because they couldn't figure out how to market it,'' Ms. Kelly said. In the end, Random House was the only publisher to make an offer, giving Ms. Sittenfeld a $40,000 advance.

headline.main: The Greatest Mystery: Making a Best Seller

docs.abstract: Article on lack of market research by publishing industry to determine relationship between book-buying public and publishers, who often are at loss to know why some books become best sellers and others languish; publishers, in estimating value, rely heavily on author's previous sales or sales of similar titles to estimate advance payments and emphasize role of intuition and sales of surprise best sellers; photos; graph (L)
docs.snippet: The advance is usually the estimate of the first year's royalties. It's often wrong.

docs.lead_paragraph: A rancher, Vitalmiro Bastos de Moura, left, was convicted of ordering the killing of Dorothy Stang, the 73-year-old American-born nun and advocate for the rain forest and peasant farmers who was shot to death on a jungle road in 2005. He was sentenced to 30 years in prison, the maximum penalty. The case was seen as an important test of justice in the largely lawless Amazon region. Of nearly 800 land-related killings in the Amazon state of Pará over the last 30 years, only four of the powerful masterminds behind them have been convicted, and none are behind bars. After the murder of Sister Dorothy, the government sent 2,000 troops to the zone and announced a logging ban on millions of Amazon acres. ''Justice was done,'' said David Stang, Sister Dorothy's brother, who flew to Brazil for the two-day trial.

docs.lead_paragraph: GRIDLOCK AHEAD? With 750 million domestic passengers expected to fly this year, ''the air transportation system is stretched thin,'' the Federal Aviation Administration said in a report. It called for increased financing for "major technology upgrades and capacity-improvement projects at major airports" to avoid what the agency said would be aviation ''gridlock.'' Last year, the F.A.A. said, airline delays were ''the worst in history.'' DELTA HELICOPTER SHUTTLE US Helicopter, which operates helicopter shuttles with 325 flights a week to Kennedy International and Newark airports and Bridgeport, Conn., is now flying into Delta Air Lines Terminal 3 at Kennedy, rather than American Airlines Terminal 9. One-way fares for the eight-minute trip from Manhattan to Kennedy or Newark start at $159. At Newark, the shuttles land next to Continental Airlines Terminal C. WORLD'S BUSIEST AIRPORTS These are the world's top 10 airports by passenger traffic in 2006, according to Airports Council International: Atlanta (84.8 million, down 1.2 percent from 2005); Chicago O'Hare (76.2 million, down 0.3 percent); London Heathrow (67.5 million, down 0.6 percent) Tokyo Haneda (65.2 million, up 3 percent); Los Angeles International (61 million, down 0.7 percent); Dallas/Fort Worth (60.1 million, up 1.3 percent); Paris Charles De Gaulle (56.8 million, up 5.6 percent); Frankfurt (52.8 million, up 1.1 percent); Beijing (48.5 million, up 18.3 percent); and Denver (47.3 million, up 9.1 percent). Taken together, however, New York's three airports accounted for by far the largest number of passengers -- 103.9 million. Kennedy International had 42.6 million passengers, up 4.2 percent; Newark had 35.5 million, up 7.4 percent; and LaGuardia had 25.8 million, down 0.3 percent. YAHOO TRAVEL SITE Yahoo upgraded its travel site, http://travel.yahoo.com, to highlight travel destinations and offers geared to individual users. Yahoo said it was not compiling databases on individuals, but rather aggregating general information gleaned from personal use of various Yahoo services, similar to the way Netflix or Amazon aggregate user information and feedback to generate suggestions to people with similar tastes. Jasper Malcolmson, director of Yahoo Travel, called it ''tapping into the collective intelligence of other like-minded travelers.'' JUST A TEST If you are passing through Los Angeles International Airport today and it looks as if a major disaster has occurred, not to worry: it's probably just a test. For three hours starting at noon, the airport will conduct a full-scale simulated aircraft disaster drill, with more than 700 participants, including 200 volunteers playing mock victims and relatives, as well as fire and police departments and medical units. The scenario for the test is that a Boeing 747 loses control and veers off the runway on landing, suffering major structural damage and an explosion that causes many fatalities and injuries and ''widespread panic,'' the agency that operates the airport said. JOE SHARKEY

docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon.com, the biggest online seller of CDs, is joining the movement against copy-protection software for digital music. It plans to sell songs that can be freely copied to any computer, cellphone or music player, including the iPod from Apple. The move could be another step toward the demise of the copy-protection systems that have frustrated some online music buyers and created confusion about compatibility between digital players and downloaded songs. Critics charge that the software has slowed the public embrace of legal digital downloads while failing to stop illicit copying, at a time when the music industry is desperate for ways to make up for declining CD sales.

docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon.com, which has haltingly moved toward selling digital music for years, said that it would start a new service that sells songs and albums without the copy-restriction software used by most online retailers. The foray by Amazon is seen as a challenge to Apple, which dominates the sale of digital music with its iTunes service. It is also seen as a potentially serious blow to digital-rights management software, which limits copying of music. The recording industry's biggest companies have long required retailers to include such restrictions to protect their music copyrights. But the winds may be shifting.

docs.lead_paragraph: RALPH AND WRIGHT: ''I wish I'd written that.'' It's a thought everyone has a couple of times a year, upon reading something particularly great. In the winter of 1952, the Book Review asked 12 writers with new books in stores to single out another book, published that year, that they wished they'd written. The answers bordered on the bizarre. John Steinbeck praised Al Capp's dialogue in his ''Li'l Abner'' cartoons. Tallulah Bankhead said she envied Adlai Stevenson's campaign speeches. Edna Ferber singled out her own novel ''Giant.'' (C'mon, people.) Then there was Ralph Ellison, whose first novel, ''Invisible Man,'' had been published earlier that year. The book Ellison said he wished he'd written was Wright Morris's novel ''The Works of Love.'' This made a certain amount of sense; Morris was a forceful and worthy, if ultimately minor, writer. Ellison's pick made even more sense if you recalled that Morris had effusively reviewed Ellison's own novel in the Book Review, calling it ''a resolutely honest, tormented, profoundly American book.'' As lit-crimes go, Ellison's back-scratching was barely a misdemeanor. But for more on Ellison's rough edges, see Brent Staples's review (Page 18) of Arnold Rampersad's new biography. NEGRO LEAGUE: Ellison clearly was more taken with Morris's review than with the one that appeared in the daily Times, written by Orville Prescott. Prescott, too, admired ''Invisible Man.'' But his praise came with some awkward qualifications, at least to today's eyes. Prescott began by calling Ellison's book ''the most impressive work of fiction by an American Negro which I have ever read.'' And he closed this way: ''No one interested in books by or about American Negroes should miss it.'' Sounds like a candidate for the Negro best-seller list! There wasn't one. Ellison's novel spent 13 weeks on the Times hardcover fiction list. NOTES: Christopher Hitchens's book ''God Is Not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything'' is new on the nonfiction list at No. 3. It's Hitchens's first book to appear here since his two-fisted attack on Bill Clinton, ''No One Left to Lie To,'' had a four-week run in the summer of 1999. ... Michael Chabon's novel ''The Yiddish Policemen's Union'' is No. 2 in its first week on the fiction list. Chabon has had only one previous best seller for adults: ''The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay'' reached No. 16 for one week in 2001. ... The novel that put Chuck Palahniuk on the map, ''Fight Club'' (1996), never made the Times best-seller list, but almost every book he's written since has. His new one, ''Rant,'' is No. 5. BIG DADDY: A few weeks ago in this space, I wrote about a surprise best seller in England -- Conn and Hal Iggulden's primer ''The Dangerous Book for Boys.'' It's now out over here, and it's No. 2 on the advice list. There's a loose, funny video ad for the book on Amazon, set to a Ramones-like punk stomp. The ad's premise? With this book's help, you can a) rescue your son from the grim tyranny of video games, b) push him down a steep hill in the rattling go-cart you've just built together and c) find that your impressed wife actually wants to have sex with you again. That's a high heap of promises. Dwight Garner

docs.lead_paragraph: When, more than 70 years ago, William Beebe became the first scientist to descend into the abyss, he described a world of twinkling lights, silvery eels, throbbing jellyfish, living strings as ''lovely as the finest lace'' and lanky monsters with needlelike teeth. ''It was stranger than any imagination could have conceived,'' he wrote in ''Half Mile Down'' (Harcourt Brace, 1934). ''I would focus on some one creature and just as its outlines began to be distinct on my retina, some brilliant, animated comet or constellation would rush across the small arc of my submarine heaven and every sense would be distracted, and my eyes would involuntarily shift to this new wonder.''

headline.main: Mysteries To Behold In the Dark Down Deep: Seadevils And Species Unknown

docs.lead_paragraph: Pope Benedict XVI tried Wednesday to quell anger in South America over his recent comments about the conversion of native populations, conceding that ''unjustifiable crimes'' were committed in the conquest of the continent 500 years ago. The pope told a weekly audience here in Italian that it was ''not possible to forget the suffering and the injustices inflicted by colonizers against the indigenous population, whose fundamental human rights were often trampled.''

headline.main: Pope Concedes Unjustifiable Crimes in Converting South Americans

docs.lead_paragraph: With an ambitious strategy for expansion, Facebook is getting in MySpace's face. Facebook, the Internet's second-largest social network, was originally popular on college campuses, but over the last year it has opened its dorm-room doors to all, and its membership rolls have exploded at triple-digit growth rates.

headline.main: Facebook Goes Off the Campus

docs.abstract: Facebook, Internet's second-largest social network that was originally popular on college campuses, is inviting thousands of technology companies and programmers to contribute features to its service in attempt to enter MySpace.com's space; some of new features, demonstrated by software developers at Facebook event in San Francisco, will allow members to recommend and listen to music, insert Amazon book reviews onto their pages, play games and join charity drives, all without leaving site; result is expected to be proliferation of new tools and activities for Facebook's 24 million active users, who have largely been limited to making online connections, sharing photos and planning events; move could foster some chaotic creativity that is more closely associated with MySpace; it could also open door to hazards like spam, and make Facebook's identity less clear; Facebook founder-chief executive Mark Zuckerberg comments; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: PAY GAP BETWEEN NO. 1 AND NO. 2 -- As executive pay has surged in most American companies, there has been a widening gap between the top executive's pay and the pay of executives a rank or two down. Few of these people are deprived, but the growing concentration of income among a select group at the top has left many others with similar talents and experience well behind. [Page A1.] INQUIRY INTO DOW CHEMICAL -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an inquiry into whether two senior executives at Dow Chemical secretly tried to put the company into play, and the unusual trading in its stock that may have resulted, according to people briefed on the matter. [C1.] COKE BUYS MAKER OF VITAMINWATER -- Directors of the Coca-Cola Company approved the purchase of Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, for $4.2 billion in cash and stock, according a person involved in the negotiations. [C1.] CONFRONTING A MANIC MARKET -- One of the biggest challenges for Chinese leaders these days lies in when and how to rein in the country's soaring stock market and, just as important, whom to pick as the next governor of the central bank. [C1.] FACEBOOK WILL HAVE MORE TO DO -- Facebook is escalating its rivalry with MySpace by inviting thousands of technology companies and programmers to contribute features that will allow members to recommend and listen to music, insert Amazon book reviews onto their pages, play games and join charity drives, all without leaving the site. [C1.] ANOTHER DROP IN PROFIT FOR GAP -- Gap Inc., the largest United States clothing retailer, reported its seventh consecutive quarterly decline in profit, and the women's apparel retailer Ann Taylor Stores also reported lower first-quarter profit. Gap said net income dropped 26 percent, to $178 million, and Ann Taylor's profit fell 19 percent, to $31.5 million. Record gasoline prices, in addition to the coldest April in a decade, discouraged shopping during the quarter, said Ann Taylor's chief executive, Kay Krill. [C2.] G.M. EXPECTS $1 BILLION CHARGE -- General Motors said that it expected to take a $1 billion charge in the second quarter and pay a total of $7 billion to cover retirement costs for workers at the Delphi Corporation, its former parts division. The company also said that it had received a new request for accounting documents from the Securities and Exchange Commission. [C2.] OUT-OF-TOWNER ON A SALES TRIP -- Donald J. Trump, along with some hoopla, came to Chicago to promote his gleaming $850 million, 1,392-foot tall hotel and condominium tower along the edge of the Chicago River. The building, under construction, still has some units for sale. ''We want to give people really good deals,'' he said, as gusts of wind buffeted his trademark hair. [A12.] DELL TO SELL IN WAL-MART -- Dell, in a first step toward transforming its ailing strategy of selling direct to consumers, said that it planned to offer computers at Wal-Mart stores, starting in June. [C4.] AN EX-CHIEF'S LEGACY -- Home Depot's ousted chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, loomed large over the company's annual shareholder meeting, as directors and executives struggled with, and at times appeared to clash over, Mr. Nardelli's legacy. [C3.] HOME SALES RISE, AND PRICES FALL -- Sales of new homes surged in April by the biggest jump in 14 years, but the median price of a new home dropped by the largest amount on record -- a sign that builders were cutting prices in an effort to move unsold homes. [C8.] The luxury-home builder Toll Brothers reported a 79 percent decline in second-quarter profit. [C8.] RECORDS SEIZED -- Justice Department investigators have seized records from the headquarters of Air Evac Lifeteam, a large operator of medical helicopters, as part of an investigation, apparently into possible health care fraud.[C10.] LONG-TERM CARE POLICIES -- A Congressional committee asked Conseco and the Penn Treaty American Corporation, two of the nation's largest sellers of long-term care insurance, to produce documents showing how the companies market long-term care policies and handle policyholder claims. [C2.] HEALTH CARE, A JOB MACHINE -- Poor-paying jobs in health care and social work have accounted for most of the job growth in New York City in the last 15 years. And in Brooklyn and the Bronx, health care now supplies about one-third of all private-sector jobs and wages. [A1.] ONLINE SPIKING GAS PRICES -- Gas prices are spiking again and some oil executives are now warning that fuel shortages -- and high prices -- could become a long-term problem. Readers weigh in on whether they've changed their driving behavior at news.blogs.nytimes.com. THE ENERGY CHALLENGE -- In a series of articles, The Times is examining how the world is, and is not, moving toward a more energy-efficient, environmentally benign future. The series is online at nytimes.com/energychallenge. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. Barnes & Noble, the world's largest book retailer, posted a first-quarter loss, but comparable-store sales rose 1.7 percent. (REUTERS) Hormel Foods posted a lower-than-expected quarterly profit and cut its full-year outlook as it struggled to pass through higher feed costs. (REUTERS)

docs.lead_paragraph: HESSERT--Richard Collings, 83, passed on May 23rd. Born in Los Angeles on November 29th, 1923, Dick was Navy Officer during WWII and a graduate of Thunderbird. His career in International Banking took him to Cuba, Columbia, Mexico and the Carribean. In addition, his love of travel extended from the Amazon to Tibet. Known as ''Poppy'' to his family, he leaves four children, Kel, Lois, Rich and Chris, their spouses, five grandchildren and many friends and relations. He is predeceased by his wife of 55 years ''Tink'', whom he cherished. His humor, kindness and love of life will be missed.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Brazilian judge on Friday indicted the two American pilots of a corporate jet that collided with an airliner over the Amazon on Sept. 29, along with four Brazilian air traffic controllers. After the crash, which killed all 154 people on the airliner, the Americans, Joseph Lepore, 42, of Bay Shore, N.Y., and Jan Paul Paladino, 35, of Westhampton, N.Y., were held in Brazil until December, then allowed to return to the United States and their Long Island homes.

headline.main: 2 American Pilots Are Indicted in Brazilian Airliner Crash

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about charges being brought in Brazil against two American pilots, whose corporate jet was involved in a mid-air collision last year over the Amazon with a Brazilian airliner that went down with 154 people aboard, misstated a Brazilian judge's position on the case. He said in a statement issued in Portuguese on Friday that the two pilots, Joseph Lepore and Jan Paul Paladino, should be charged with exposing an aircraft to danger; he did not say they were guilty of having done so.

docs.lead_paragraph: After completing his 67-day, 3,278-mile swim down the Amazon River on April 8, Martin Strel, a 53-year-old Slovene, did not make the same mistake he made after finishing his 2,360-mile swim down the Mississippi in 2002 -- this time, instead of going home to Trebnje, he came to Hollywood. ''Jay Leno called us 37 times,'' says Strel's son, Borut, who manages his swimming expeditions, ''but we had appointments in Slovenia.'' But not today. Fifteen days after climbing out of the Amazon in Belém, Brazil, where he was promptly loaded into an ambulance for a ride to a local hospital (''with blood pressure at near heart attack levels,'' his official Web site reported), Strel and Borut are in Los Angeles, sipping red wine with a documentary filmmaker at a yellow-walled Italian restaurant in Marina del Rey. The filmmaker and his crew were with Strel for every stroke of his journey from Atalaya, Peru, to the Amazon's mouth, shooting a documentary, ''Big River Man,'' which is now being edited. Strel and Borut are in California to help with the editing, to brush up Strel's English in preparation for the film's publicity tour (and, they hope, a string of speaking engagements) and to field calls from the news media. ''I tell him, 'Why suffer again?' '' Borut explains. '' 'Why should we swim another river now? We should do show business. This is much more comfortable.' ''

headline.main: Swimming for Peace in the Middle East, for the Dalai Lama, for Clean Water, for the Rain Forest. We'll Drink to That.

docs.snippet: It doesn’t take much for world-record breaker Martin Strel to get the most out of life.

docs.lead_paragraph: THESE days, Google seems to be doing everything, everywhere. It takes pictures of your house from outer space, copies rare Sanskrit books in India, charms its way onto Madison Avenue, picks fights with Hollywood and tries to undercut Microsoft's software dominance. But at its core, Google remains a search engine. And its search pages, blue hyperlinks set against a bland, white background, have made it the most visited, most profitable and arguably the most powerful company on the Internet. Google is the homework helper, navigator and yellow pages for half a billion users, able to find the most improbable needles in the world's largest haystack of information in just the blink of an eye.

headline.main: Inside the Black Box

docs.abstract: Article on work of Amit Singhal and hundreds of other Google engineers who are constantly tweaking search engine in quest to close gap between what users are seeking and what they are able to find; Google believes that its ability to decrease number of times it leaves searchers disappointed is crucial to fending off competition from Yahoo and Microsoft and preserving advertising gold mine that search represents; chart; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Google’s top minds offer a peek inside the algorithm that provides search results for half a billion users.

docs.lead_paragraph: The illegal lottery known as ''the animal game'' is as visible a part of the urban landscape here as Ipanema beach or Sugarloaf mountain. On thousands of street corners, vendors sit all day at little wooden booths, pads of paper in hand, taking money from bettors, who return later to check results posted on lampposts or walls. The bosses of the billion-dollar industry known in Portuguese as the ''jogo do bicho,'' on the other hand, have long preferred to operate in the shadows. That was, at least, until a burgeoning corruption scandal suddenly thrust them into an uncomfortable national spotlight.

headline.main: Brazilian Numbers Game Ties Officials to Mobsters

docs.abstract: Raids by Brazilian Federal Police have uncovered big payoffs to judges, police officers and lawyers from bosses who run Brazil's ubiquitous illegal lottery known as 'animal game'; more than 40 people face criminal charges, yet game goes on; game is deeply embedded in Brazilian culture and judicial rulings favorable to game's powerful bosses have blunted effect of prohibition; photos (M)
docs.snippet: A burgeoning corruption scandal has suddenly thrust the bosses of the billion-dollar industry known as “the animal game” into an uncomfortable spotlight.

docs.lead_paragraph: The eternal tension between Brazil's need for economic growth and the damage that can cause to the environment are nowhere more visible than here in this corner of the western Amazon region. More than one-quarter of this rugged frontier state, Rondônia, has been deforested, the highest rate in the Amazon. Over the years, ranchers, miners and loggers have routinely invaded nature reserves and Indian reservations.

headline.main: Both Sides Say Dam Project Is Pivotal Issue for Brazil

docs.abstract: Proposal to build $11 billion hydroelectric project in western Amazon region of Brazil on Madeira River, that may have world's most diverse fish stocks, has set off new controversy; Pres Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has made economy top priority of his second term; he envisions such large public works projects as best way to stimulate growth; Brazil's environmental movement has steadily lost influence under da Silva, who has been courting business establishment since taking power; government's environmental agency has refused to license dam projects, but proposal is far from dead and continues to have da Silva's support; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When the social networking Web site Facebook opened itself to third-party businesses two weeks ago, users found new features from a few dozen outside sites, including Microsoft, Amazon, and just one political campaign: Senator Barack Obama's. The Obama campaign's inclusion in the much-publicized opening of Facebook set off immediate buzz in the online political world. The campaign got an early crack at the millions of Facebook users, and Mr. Obama gained some free publicity. Some argued that he was getting an in-kind campaign contribution. And the fact that a Facebook founder, Chris Hughes, is an adviser to Mr. Obama added fuel to the fire.

headline.main: Facebook Free-for-All

docs.abstract: Sen Barack Obama's presidential campaign takes advantage of Facebook's decision to open itself to third-party businesses; some people in online political world question whether Obama got in-kind contribution and was favored because Chris Hughes, founder of site, is adviser to him; Kenneth Gross, election law expert, says Internet is excluded from restrictions or giveaways of other forms of media (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: There is a crisis brewing in America's vast forest lands, but it has little to do with the health of the woods: the acreage is essentially the same as it was a century ago, and there is over 30 percent more wood volume per acre than in 1952. At stake are large tracts of private forest that are at risk of falling into mismanagement, subdivision or being sold for development.

headline.main: Family Forestry

docs.lead_paragraph: The plain metal rowboats at the Central Park Boathouse are surprisingly similar to the skiff that Bear Grylls commandeered in Alaska during an episode of ''Man vs. Wild,'' his hit series on the Discovery Channel. Except that his leaked, lacked oars and eventually sank among a pack of ice floes, forcing him to strip down to a T-shirt and swim to shore. The water was so frigid that he started hyperventilating as his pulse raced to the heart-attack zone. But then what kind of survival show would it be without a near brush with death? Tonight at 9 is the new season's premiere, and Mr. Grylls has to find food, water and a way out of the Florida Everglades with only a flint, a water bottle and a knife. There is razor grass and mud holes that could inhale a jeep in a single breath. Without giving too much away, let's just say that those with a soft spot for Kermit the Frog might want to avert their eyes during lunch.

headline.main: Are You Tough Enough? An Adventurer's Guide To Surviving the Wilds

docs.abstract: Profile of and interview with Bear Grylls, wildlife adventurer who is host of Discovery Channel's hit series Man vs Wild; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Bear Grylls survived Everest, the British Special Air Services and a broken back before he became known for “Man vs. Wild,” a hit series on the Discovery Channel.

Jimi Hendrix had built Electric Lady in the late 1960s, and Mr. Earle pointed out that ''there are some good ghosts here.'' ''Yeah,'' Mr. Adams blithely responded. ''There are the ghosts of about 45 speedballs from when I was recording here a year or two ago,'' referring to a mixture of heroin and cocaine.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Karitiana Indians remember it, the first researchers to draw their blood came here in the late 1970s, shortly after the Amazon tribe began sustained contact with the outside world. In 1996, another team visited, promising medicine if the Karitiana would just give more blood, so they dutifully lined up again. But that promise was never fulfilled, and since then the world has expanded again for the Karitiana through the arrival of the Internet. Now they have been enraged by a simple discovery: their blood and DNA collected during that first visit are being sold by an American concern to scientists around the world for $85 a sample.

headline.main: In the Amazon, Giving Blood but Getting Nothing

docs.abstract: Karitiana Indians in Brazil's western Amazon are enraged to discover that blood and DNA samples they have donated to researchers at times since late 1970's are being sold by Coriell Cell Repositories to scientists around world for $85 a sample, with no compensation for their tiny remote tribe; Surui and Yanomami tribes lodge similiar complaints; Coriell, New Jersey-based nonprofit group that stores human genetic material, says samples were obtained legally through researcher and approved by National Institutes of Health; Joseph Mintzer says his group has no profit intent and distributes cell lines only to scientists who agree not to commercialize results; French company also has obtained samples; Judith Greenberg of National Institutes of Health says samples were legitimately obtained for benefit of mankind; Indians say they did not understand what was involved and were promised medicines and money; photos; map (Kyowa Journal) (M)
docs.snippet: The practice of collecting blood samples from Amazon Indians has aroused widespread suspicions in Brazil.

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR years Internet merchants have poured millions of dollars into new technologies to make their sites easier to use. So why aren't online customers happier? Customer satisfaction levels have remained almost flat through the last several years, according to a survey of about 20,000 online shoppers recently released by ForeSee Results, a consulting and research firm based in Ann Arbor, Mich. The problem, according to Larry Freed, ForeSee's chief executive, is not so much that consumers have ignored the many improvements made in recent years. Rather, he said, they still expect more from Internet shopping than it has delivered.

docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon has recorded nearly 1.6 million global online orders for ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,'' the seventh and final novel in the J. K. Rowling saga of the boy wizard, Reuters reported yesterday. Amazon said the demand had set a record, eclipsing the 1.5 million copies ordered before the release of the previous book in the series, ''Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince.'' Amazon predicted that orders for the new book would rise by ''many more hundreds of thousands of copies'' before its release on July 21. ... St. Ann's Warehouse announced its 2007-8 season, which includes ''Black Watch,'' the new National Theater of Scotland production of Gregory Burke's play based on interviews with Scottish soldiers in Iraq; ''The Veiled Monologues'' and ''Is.Man,'' two works by the Dutch writer Adelheid Roosen about life in contemporary Muslim societies; and a Samuel Beckett festival consisting of performances, readings and master classes put together by the Gate Theater in Dublin. ... Following the Metropolitan Opera, the Glyndebourne Festival Opera plans to present its productions on screens in movie theaters around Britain beginning in the fall, The Times of London reported. Initially, three productions, each priced at $15 a ticket, will be shown in 10 cities. The operas will be Wagner's ''Tristan and Isolde,'' Mozart's ''Così fan Tutte'' and a third to be announced.

docs.lead_paragraph: Perhaps it is nothing more than a legend, as skeptics say. Or maybe it is real, as those who claim to have seen it avow. But the mere mention of the mapinguary, the giant slothlike monster of the Amazon, is enough to send shivers down the spines of almost all who dwell in the world's largest rain forest. The folklore here is full of tales of encounters with the creature, and nearly every Indian tribe in the Amazon, including those that have had no contact with one another, have a word for the mapinguary (pronounced ma-ping-wahr-EE). The name is usually translated as ''the roaring animal'' or ''the fetid beast.''

headline.main: A Huge Amazon Monster Is Only a Myth. Or Is It?

docs.snippet: Nearly every Indian tribe in the Amazon, including those that have had no contact with one another, have a word for the mapinguary, or “the roaring animal”  but is it still out there?

docs.lead_paragraph: SO omnipotent is the Apple digital music machine that just the possibility of one of its main suppliers holding back some of its music from Apple's iTunes music store is enough to make headlines and send shock waves. That is what happened last week when the Universal Music Group let Apple know that it would no longer grant the company guaranteed access to its coming releases. Officially, Universal had no comment, but an executive briefed on the negotiations said the music company was merely interested in keeping its options open as it does with most other retailers in the brick-and-mortar world.

docs.lead_paragraph: European competitors are trying to undermine Brazil's biofuels production by raising environmental concerns, President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva said. Brazil is the world's largest exporter of ethanol and a pioneer in developing biodiesel. It started a program to fuel cars with ethanol derived from sugar cane 30 years ago. ''We have adversaries that will make up any kind of slander against the quality of ethanol and biodiesel,'' Mr. da Silva said on his weekly radio show. Asked about reports in European newspapers that biofuels could contribute to deforesting the Amazon, he said, ''I told them the Portuguese, who arrived in 1500, introduced sugar cane 470 years ago and it didn't reach the Amazon for a simple reason -- the temperature isn't suitable.'' The United States and Brazil signed an accord in March to jointly promote biofuel production in South America and Africa.

docs.lead_paragraph: There are a few givens at Allen & Company's rarefied annual summit for media moguls in Sun Valley, Idaho. Titans arrive in a conga line of private jets, attend some gold-plated panels followed by cocktails, and occasionally head out to the paths of the Sun Valley Resort for a little speed-dating. The guest list is always incandescent -- hey, there's Bill Gates! Tony Blair! Rupert Murdoch! -- and the air is thick with rumors of deals. This year, the titans arrived, the guest list shimmered, but the deals didn't happen. The only transaction I saw consummated was Richard D. Parsons selling a chair on the patio bar for 45 cents to Michael S. Ovitz (and come to think of it, no money changed hands).

headline.main: High Wattage At Sun Valley, But No Deals

docs.abstract: Media Equation column discusses Allen & Company's annual summit for media moguls in Sun Valley, Idaho; old and new media representatives are in attendance; article holds that conference has lost its relevance and highlights differences between generations rather than helping them work together to move industry forward (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An Airbus 320 with 176 people on board skidded off a runway while landing Tuesday night at the main airport in São Paulo, Brazil's largest city, and crashed into an office building and a gas station across a highway, setting off a conflagration that took firefighters more than six hours to bring under control. The governor of the state of São Paulo, José Serra, who was at the scene, said that the chances of passengers and the crew having survived the crash and ensuing explosion that broke the airplane into at least two pieces were almost zero, according to the Web site of the local newspaper, Folha de São Paulo.

headline.main: Plane Crashes in Brazil; 176 Feared Dead

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York Times is not a name you normally associate with open-source software. Perhaps it makes you think of checking in with our Web site during the workday or lazy Sunday mornings with the printed paper, but never code. Which is a pity, since there are plenty of ways in which code -- and increasingly, open-source code -- is critical at The Times. We're not just talking about the Web site (at least 10 million hits a day, incidentally), but also the archives (4 terabytes of images), and the gigabytes of databases on subjects like campaign finance. There's a lot of architecture working behind the scenes, and more and more of it is based on open-source software.

docs.lead_paragraph: Government prosecutors on Thursday were seeking an injunction to shut down the airport here after the worst airline disaster in Brazilian history, arguing that the airport is a menace both to passengers and residents. The death toll from the crash of TAM Flight 3054, which skidded off a short, slippery runway at Congonhas Airport on Tuesday night and exploded as it plowed into an office building and gas station, has now reached 188. As many as a dozen people are still missing and presumed dead, and the charred and fragmented state of the bodies that have been recovered has slowed identification and burial.

headline.main: Prosecutors Seek to Close São Paulo Airport in Wake of Brazil's Worst Airline Disaster

docs.abstract: Brazilian prosecutors seek to close Congonhas Airport in Sao Paulo, country's busiest, two days after TAM Flight 3054 skidded off rainy runway and exploded as it plowed into office building and gas station; 188 people were killed and dozen more are missing and presumed dead in worst airline disaster in Brazilian history; airport authorities oppose closing as impractical; some aviation analysts believe cause of accident was mechanical failure or pilot error rather than condition of runway; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Government prosecutors argued that Congonhas, the country’s busiest airport, is a menace both to passengers and residents.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the death toll climbing after the fiery crash of a crowded Airbus here on Tuesday night, Brazilians responded Wednesday with anger and renewed calls for the government to act immediately to end the deepening aviation crisis that has tormented the country for nearly a year. More than 176 people are confirmed dead in the accident, the worst in Brazil's history and the second in less than 10 months. But even as Brazilians mourned, the focus of their discussion was shifting to how to prevent yet another disaster.

headline.main: Brazil Demands Solution to Aviation Crisis

docs.abstract: Brazilians respond with anger and renewed calls for government to act immediately to end deepening aviation crisis after fiery crash of crowded TAM Airlines Airbus in Sao Paulo; more than 179 people are confirmed dead in accident, second worst in Brazil's history and second crash in less than 10 months; Pres Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva creates emergency cabinet group to deal with disaster; it is unclear who is addressing larger array of problems that include outdated airports and rebelling air traffic controllers; Air Force Ministry and pair of civilian agencies that deal with aviation are minimizing their responsibilities for situation; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Even as Brazilians mourned in the wake of the fiery crash on Tuesday, the focus of their discussion was shifting to how to prevent yet another disaster.

docs.lead_paragraph: Breaking three days of silence after the worst airline disaster in Brazilian history, President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva went on television on Friday night to assure worried Brazilians that he had ordered immediate changes in the country's flawed civil aviation system. The Brazilian government is ''taking every step in our power to reduce the risk of new tragedies,'' Mr. da Silva said. He also urged Brazilians, who have had to cope with two major disasters in less than 10 months and who are calling for the government to step forward and take responsibility for the crisis, to remain ''serene so as not to commit injustices.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Some of Harry Potter's magic has rubbed off on Amazon.com. The company, based in Seattle, announced today that its second-quarter net income increased more than threefold on revenue that rose 35 percent.

headline.main: Aided by Harry Potter Fans, Amazon Triples Its Profit

docs.abstract: Amazon.com says second-quarter net income increased more than threefold on revenue that rose 35 percent; net income was $78 million compared with $22 million year earlier; revenue increased to $2.89 billion; company's shares rise more than 21.4 percent to around $84.09 in after-hours trading (M)
docs.snippet: The online retailer announced Tuesday that its second-quarter net income increased more than threefold, with revenue up 35 percent.

docs.lead_paragraph: Wow. As of this writing, Amazon's stock price is up more than 25 percent today after its second blockbuster quarterly earnings report in a row. As I wrote yesterday, Wall Street is beginning to view Amazon more as a technology company, with the attendant high-multiple valuation, than a plain old low-margin retailer. And one significant contributor to that perceptual shift is the growth of Amazon's Marketplaces business, which lets visitors to Amazon buy from third-party merchants, instead of directly from Amazon.com.

headline.main: The Loser in Amazon's Results: EBay?

docs.abstract: Amazon's torrid earnings report may spell problems for eBay.com. Merchants are finding that Amazon's marketplace program is a better place to sell their wares.
docs.snippet: Amazon's torrid earnings report may spell problems for eBay.com. Merchants are finding that Amazon's marketplace program is a better place to sell their wares.

docs.lead_paragraph: HOW would you like to use your video game console to tune in ''Big Love'' on your television? Or perhaps use your DVD player to download ''The Departed'' while you watch a ballgame? Those features are now possible, thanks to some new devices and recent rule changes governing cable television service. Just don't throw out your old cable box quite yet. The key to this new world of TV entertainment is a Federal Communications Commission rule that went into effect July 1. Cable companies in the United States now have to separate the security functions that prevent you from watching channels you haven't paid for from the TV tuner box most of us rent.

headline.main: Cable Without a Cable Box, And TV Shows Without a TV

docs.abstract: Cable companies in US have to separate security functions that prevent users from watching channels they have not paid for from TV tuner box most rent; practical result of new Federal Communications Commission rule is that cable companies have to supply set-top boxes that come with removable CableCard; cards, which look like PC Cards used in notebook computers, contain information necessary to unscramble digital cable channels; they could allow other equipment to become much more versatile; cards are designed to be inserted into host of other devices, including televisions, digital video recorders and computers; companies like Toshiba, Panasonic, Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard have sought this breakthrough for years because it opens array of features for CableCard-equipped devices; cable companies have resisted idea for years; photos (L)
docs.snippet: CableCARDs, which contain the information necessary to unscramble digital cable channels like HBO, could allow other equipment to become much more versatile.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva on Wednesday replaced the country's defense minister, whose duties include oversight of civil aviation. The move came eight days after the deadliest air disaster in Brazilian history. With the fallout spreading from last week's accident at São Paulo's Congonhas airport, Mr. da Silva said he was replacing Defense Minister Waldir Pires with Nelson Jobim, a highly respected former Supreme Court president and justice minister. Mr. da Silva said at Mr. Jobim's swearing-in ceremony that Mr. Pires had resigned voluntarily, but a government news release said he had been asked to do so.

headline.main: Defense Minister Is Replaced As Brazil's Air Crisis Grows

docs.abstract: Brazilian Pres Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva replaces Defense Min Waldir Pires with Nelson Jobim, as fallout spreads from nation's worst air disaster, when TAM Airlines plane crashed at Sao Paulo's Congonhas airport killing 199 people; defense minister has oversight of civil aviation; pressure was mounting for da Silva to make changes; latest accident leads to international criticism of Brazil's flawed aviation system; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The move came after President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva had assured Brazilians that he had ordered changes in the country’s flawed civil aviation system.

docs.lead_paragraph: AT her all-day princess-theme party for her graduation from preschool, Lyra Alvis had her face painted, went first down the water slide and was even allowed to eat the flower on the cake. ''It was the best day of my life,'' said Lyra, 5, who lives in Nashville. At least until bedtime. That is when her father, Lance Alvis, did something he'd never done before: Midway through a book that was a gift from a friend, he insisted she pick out something different to read.

docs.lead_paragraph: Depending on one's point of view, the World Wildlife Fund's financial support of a nature reserve here on the Rio Negro is either part of a laudable attempt to conserve the Amazon jungle -- or the leading edge of a nefarious plot by foreign environmental groups to wrest control of the world's largest rain forest from Brazil and replace it with international rule. In 2003, after signing an agreement with the WWF and the World Bank, the Brazilian government created the Amazon Region Protected Areas program. Since then, more than a score of national parks and reserves covering an area larger than New York, New Jersey and Connecticut combined have been brought into that network and provided with an infusion of new funds.

headline.main: In the Amazon: Conservation or Colonialism?

docs.abstract: Powerful business and political groups in Brazil that want to integrate Amazon into country's economy remain suspcious of Amazon Regional Protected Areas program, set up in 2003 by Brazilian government in concert with World Wildlife Fund and World Bank; business interests call conservation efforts new form of colonialism, charging that groups want to block devlopment in Brazil; views are widely held, with 75 percent of people surveyed expressing distrust of environmental groups; notion that foreigners covet Amazon has long been widespread, fed in part by anxiety about central government's tenuous control of region; map; photos (M)
docs.snippet: A recent survey showed that a majority of Brazilians feel the country’s natural riches could provoke a foreign invasion and many distrusted environmental groups.

docs.lead_paragraph: I had dinner with my daughter, Kate, near Union Square in Manhattan last Friday, and afterward, as we walked toward the subway, we saw a long line snaking around the corner. ''Do you know what that is?'' she asked. I didn't. ''Harry Potter.'' Of course! At midnight, the seventh and final installment of the best-selling book series of all time, ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,'' would go on sale. The sixth book, ''Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince,'' published in 2005, sold almost seven million copies in the United States within the first 24 hours; it was widely expected that ''Deathly Hallows'' would beat that record. (It did.) The line was filled with people of all ages, some wearing wizard robes, all eager to get into the 18th Street Barnes & Noble, and be among the first to find out how the author J. K. Rowling would wrap up the series.

headline.main: Making Money On Potter? That's Magic

docs.lead_paragraph: THE guide piloted our boat into the roiling rapids and we hit the first wave head-on. The force lifted us skyward and dropped us with a thud. We smacked into the next few waves in this set of rapids and got bucketsful of water in our faces as we shrieked and laughed. Then our guide circled around and we hit the rapids again. It's one of the neater tricks in outdoor recreation: shooting a section of rapids, then repeating the process several times before moving upriver to tackle the next section. This is river rafting, Bay of Fundy style. The bay lays claim to the world's highest tides, and twice daily its tidal flow surges inland into the Shubenacadie River in Nova Scotia with enough force to reverse the river's natural flow.

headline.main: When the Bay of Fundy Swells, A River Roller Coaster Begins

docs.lead_paragraph: It may seem obsessive, but every day -- sometimes hourly -- Aaron Shepard checks the Amazon.com sales rankings for his 12 self-published books. He even created a Web site, www.salesrankexpress.com, that lets authors check their Amazon rankings instantly. ''People want to know where their book stands, just for the thrill of that score,'' says Mr. Shepard, whose top seller, ''The Business of Writing for Children,'' clocked in at 1,834th during one random check last week, and at 2,070th during another one. He says it sells 250 to 450 copies a month.

headline.main: The Highs and the Lows of Rankings on Amazon

docs.abstract: Amazon.com system of ranking books gives authors instant feedback and quick, easy way to keep track of book sales; Amazon says rankings, which reflect current tastes, are updated hourly through complicated algorithm for millions of items sold on its site; information such as sales history, with recent sales weighted more heavily, factor into book's position in rankings; some authors 'game the system' by purchasing copies themselves or having others do so; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Deforestation of the Amazon rainforest from August 2005 to July 2006 decreased by 25 percent since the previous 12 months, the Environmental Ministry said. It said that 8,774 square miles, almost the size of New Hampshire, were cut down, significantly less that the 11,745 square miles a year earlier. It was the second year in a row that deforestation fell.

docs.lead_paragraph: If you have ever been lost on the tiny, twisting, one-way back streets of Prague, Brussels or Milan, you have a pretty good idea why navigation devices that use the Global Positioning System are vastly more popular in Europe than in the United States. But what if that same device could also inform you about an accident on your route just minutes after it happened, or could tell you the average time a drive would take depending on the hour and day of the week?

docs.lead_paragraph: The Internet offers immediate access to articles about every breaking news event anywhere in the world. But no one in the media business has quite figured out how to exploit that revolutionary fact. A growing number of large Web companies like Yahoo, Google and AOL and a menagerie of start-ups like Digg and Topix.net offer a comprehensive menu of news headlines that link to articles elsewhere online. These sites are called news aggregators, and though some have large audiences, the companies that run them have yet to figure out how to turn them into enduring businesses with unique identities.

headline.main: Names in the News Get a Way to Respond

docs.abstract: Google asks people or companies mentioned in news articles to comment on reports; responses are posted on Google News site, among largest news aggregators on Internet; media professionals criticize experiment, saying Google does not understand complexities of undertaking; while some traditional media organizations feel threatened by growing crop of online aggregators, most view them as ways to drive traffic to their sites; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As more fathers have taken hands-on roles in child rearing, their inventions are increasingly inspired by personal experiences.

headline.main: My Dad, American Inventor
headline.print_headline: My Dad, American Inventor

docs.snippet: As more fathers have taken hands-on roles in child rearing, their inventions are increasingly inspired by personal experiences.

docs.lead_paragraph: TOMMY HABEEB just wanted to be one of the new breed of involved dads: the hands-on guys who preside over bath time without creating a flood; the ones who return home from work early enough to crawl after their children toward the realm of make-believe. His ambitions did not include inventing the Water Bottle Nipple Adaptor. Inspiration struck Mr. Habeeb on a sweltering afternoon in Dallas, though, when he found himself with a cold bottle of water and no way for the baby slung across his chest to drink from it. In short order, he was in his kitchen hacksawing off the top of a baby bottle and improvising a coupling to allow the nipple to be screwed onto almost any water bottle.

headline.main: My Dad, American Inventor

docs.abstract: Inventions created by stay-at-home dads and fathers, who are spending more time with their children, noted; Families and Work Institute, research group, study published in 2002 finds that Generation X fathers spend average of 3.4 hours each workday with their children compared with only 2.2 hours for Boomer generation; holds that trend is likely to continue; some father-created inventions to make parenting easier described; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Manda Bala'' (''Send a Bullet''), a flashy documentary about corruption, injustice and frog farming in Brazil, is a weird hybrid of political exposé and sensationalistic fluff. As it flip-flops between one mode and the other, it suggests a combination of ''Darwin's Nightmare,'' the recent deadly serious French documentary about the despoiling of Lake Victoria, and ''Mondo Cane,'' the sensationalistic 1962 film that inaugurated a genre of globe-trotting documentary voyeurism. Produced and directed by Jason Kohn, ''Manda Bala,'' which was named best documentary at this year's Sundance Film Festival, is packed with bad news that isn't nearly as fresh as the movie pretends. It has already been widely reported that in São Paulo, a city of 20 million where the rich live side by side with the destitute, an epidemic of kidnappings has produced a thriving business in bulletproof cars.

headline.print_headline: Building a Brand Name, Via Business Cards

docs.snippet: Among Internet businesses, perhaps only VistaPrint has managed to reach a market value of more than $1 billion by getting customers to hand out millions of promotional messages for it.

docs.lead_paragraph: AMONG Internet businesses, perhaps only one has managed to reach a market value of more than $1 billion by getting customers to hand out millions of promotional messages for it. The company is not Amazon, eBay or even Google. Rather, it is VistaPrint, a printing company that has strung together 28 profitable quarters by selling -- and giving away -- business cards. The free cards, of which VistaPrint has distributed 2.5 billion, carry the company's marketing message on the back.

headline.main: Building a Brand Name, Via Business Cards

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's three largest booksellers have made decisions about carrying ''If I Did It,'' O. J. Simpson's book about the 1994 murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman, Publishers Weekly reported yesterday. Amazon and Barnes & Noble's Web site (barnesandnoble.com) said they would carry the book. But Barnes & Noble stores will not carry it, a spokesman said, because the company's buyers believe there is insufficient customer interest to justify stocking it. Barnes & Noble will special order the book for anyone who requests it, but the decision is a blow to the book's publisher, Beaufort Books, which has minimal distribution in independent stores. Borders stores, on the other hand, will carry the title, but ''will not promote or market the book in any way,'' a spokeswoman said. ''If I Did It'' was to have been published last November by ReganBooks, an imprint of HarperCollins, with an announced printing of 400,000. But it was dropped in response to widespread outrage.
