The lawyer, Joel R. Weiss, cited the Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty, which he said would allow the pilots to testify about the case from their home country.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a retail market keen on the word “natural,” exports of Brazil’s beauty products have been rising quickly.

headline.main: Beautifying the World With Amazon Ingredients
headline.sub: A Nation Sells the World on Products Based on Amazon Ingredients    ;
headline.print_headline: Beauty and the Brazilians

docs.snippet: In a retail market keen on the word “natural,” exports of Brazil’s beauty products have been rising quickly.

docs.lead_paragraph: Brazilians' longtime devotion to the body beautiful -- whether it be spending fortunes on perfumes and cosmetics, slimming down to fit into minuscule swimsuits or revealing body waxing -- is paying off. Exports of the country's beauty products have been rising quickly in the last few years. In 2006, Brazilian companies exported $484 million of cosmetics, toiletries and fragrances, said João Carlos Basilio da Silva, president of the Brazilian Toiletry, Perfumery and Cosmetic Association. That was up 152 percent from 2001, he said.

headline.main: Beauty and the Brazilians

docs.abstract: Exports of Brazil's beauty products have been rising quickly in last few years; Brazilian companies exported $484 million of cosmetics and fragrances in 2006, increase of 152 percent from 2001; less than 1 percent of Brazilian Amazon plants provide active ingredients for cosmetics; Brazilian producers do not claim that those ingredients are better or healthier than those found in species growing elsewhere or that their ingredients are superior to traditional components like animal fats; they do believe their 'Brazilianness' is major factor in rising sales; industry executives in Brazil say country's products are seen as somehow purer than ones from other parts of world; executives also say sales have been helped by Brazilians' image as healthy, attractive people who go all out to look good; main destination for Brazilian beauty products is still South America, accounting for 61 percent of Brazil's exports; with domestic market of 188 million people, economies of scale enable Brazil to produce beauty products for significantly less than its neighbors; that has prompted some companies to close their operations in places like Chile, Uruguay and Bolivia and move production to Brazil; Russia, Cuba and Angola have emerged as important customers; photos (L)
docs.snippet: In a retail market keen on the word “natural,” exports of Brazil’s beauty products have been rising quickly.

docs.snippet: The organization has filed a civil lawsuit against the online bookstore, alleging that selling subscriptions to two cockfighting magazines violates animal cruelty laws.

docs.lead_paragraph: Michael Vick, the Atlanta Falcons quarterback, is expected to plead guilty today to federal dog-fighting charges and face up to five years in prison, but the Humane Society of the United States has a bigger target: Amazon.com. The online bookstore sells subscriptions to two cockfighting magazines, The Feathered Warrior and The Gamecock, even though cockfighting has been declared illegal in all states (until Louisiana's ban takes effect next summer, the activity remains legal in parts of the state).

docs.lead_paragraph: During the tech bust, GSI Commerce Inc. increased business by buying distressed online retailers. Now the company hopes it can raise its growth through an acquisition of a different kind.

headline.main: Late to Web Retailing? There’s Still Money There
headline.print_headline: Late to Web Retailing? There’s Still Money There

docs.snippet: During the tech bust, GSI Commerce Inc. increased business by buying distressed online retailers. Now the company hopes it can raise its growth through an acquisition of a different kind.

docs.lead_paragraph: DURING the tech bust, GSI Commerce Inc. was the company that salvaged many operations. Beginning in 2000, as start-ups failed, GSI increased its business by buying distressed online retailers like Fogdog.com and Ashford.com, and running the entire operations more efficiently than the retailers could themselves. Now the business, which makes money by helping companies like Toys ''R'' Us and Linens 'n Things operate online stores, hopes it can again raise its growth through an acquisition of a different kind.

headline.main: Late to Web Retailing? There's Still Money There

docs.abstract: GSI Commerce announces that it will purchase Accretive Commerce for $97.5 million in cash in effort to maintain its position online; Web retailing segment is still experiencing growth, even for businesses late to market; acquisition essentially eliminates CSI Commerce's competition, while improving company's flexibility; photo (M)
docs.snippet: During the tech bust, GSI Commerce Inc. increased business by buying distressed online retailers. Now the company hopes it can raise its growth through an acquisition of a different kind.

docs.lead_paragraph: A world-renowned primatologist’s research of monkeys in the Amazon has led to a prison sentence of nearly 16 years in Brazil.

headline.main: As Brazil Defends Its Bounty, Rules Ensnare Scientists
headline.print_headline: As Brazil Defends Its Bounty, Rules Ensnare Scientists

docs.snippet: A world-renowned primatologist’s research of monkeys in the Amazon has led to a prison sentence of nearly 16 years in Brazil.

docs.lead_paragraph: Marc van Roosmalen is a world-renowned primatologist whose research in the Amazon has led to the discovery of five species of monkeys and a new primate genus. But precisely because of that work, Dr. van Roosmalen was recently sentenced to nearly 16 years in prison and jailed in Manaus, Brazil. Earlier in August, his lawyers managed to get him freed while they appeal his conviction on charges stemming from an investigation into alleged biopiracy. But scientists here and abroad are outraged, and they describe the case as only the most glaring example of laws and government policies they say are xenophobic and increasingly stifling scientific inquiry.

headline.main: As Brazil Defends Its Bounty, Rules Ensnare Scientists

docs.abstract: Scientists wishing to conduct research in Brazil have to get authorization from as many as five government agencies; final approval can take up to two years; government claims that delay is because of budgetary and staffing problems within agencies; says that biopiracy has become such problem that strict regulations need to be in place; Dr Marc van Roosmalen, world-renowned primatologist who has worked extensively in Brazilian jungle, was recently sentenced to 16 years in prison for allegedly biopiracy; case described; photos (M)
docs.snippet: A world-renowned primatologist’s research of monkeys in the Amazon has led to a prison sentence of nearly 16 years in Brazil.

headline.main: Rare Dolphin Seen in China, Experts Say
headline.print_headline: Rare Dolphin Seen in China, Experts Say

docs.snippet: Experts say a large white animal swimming in the Yangtze River is a member of a dolphin species unique to China and feared extinct.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Chinese man has videotaped a large white animal swimming in the Yangtze River that experts say is a member of a dolphin species unique to China and feared extinct, the official Xinhua news agency said Wednesday. The last confirmed sighting of a member of the species, the long-beaked, nearly blind baiji, was in 2004. After an international team failed to find a single dolphin on a six-week expedition along the Yangtze last year, the species was classified as critically endangered and possibly extinct. But the videotape from central Anhui Province may renew slim hopes for the survival of the creature, also known as the white-flag dolphin.

headline.main: Rare Dolphin Seen in China, Experts Say

headline.main: The Author Will Take Q.’s Now
headline.print_headline: The Author Will Take Q.’s Now

docs.snippet: To meet your favorite author these days, you don’t wait in line, you go online.

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the publication in July of her first book, ''The Late Bloomer's Revolution,'' Amy Cohen imagined a promotional tour of bookstores in Sydney, Australia. And Paris. And a few places closer to home, New York City, would work, too. Then her publicist at Hyperion told her, as Ms. Cohen recalled somewhat tongue in cheek, ''You aren't going to Scarsdale.'' Instead of some far-flung Barnes & Noble, there was Prillboyle. Rather than Borders, there was Bluestalking Reader. Ms. Cohen, a former television writer for ''Spin City'' and ''Caroline in the City,'' was surprised to learn that most of her ''appearances'' would be on blogs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Authors who monitor sales of their books online were dealt a bit of a blow last month, when Amazon.com stopped providing information to the public about how many copies of each book it had in stock. ''While quantity is certainly an interesting piece of data, that information did not help software developers drive traffic to Amazon.com,'' said Drew Herdener, a spokesman for Amazon. ''Customers could still make a choice on whether or not to buy a product without having to know how many are in stock.''

docs.lead_paragraph: NBC Universal significantly deepened its relationship with Amazon's digital video download service after a dispute with Apple over the pricing of television shows on iTunes. The media conglomerate, part of General Electric, said yesterday that Amazon had agreed to give it something that Apple would not: greater flexibility in the pricing and packaging of video downloads. As a result, NBC Universal said it had agreed to sell a wide variety of television programming on Amazon's fledgling Unbox download service, including the drama ''Heroes'' and the comedies ''The Office'' and ''30 Rock.'' Episodes will be available on Unbox the day after they are shown.

docs.lead_paragraph: Anton Yelchin's voice was still changing when, at barely 15 years old, he starred alongside Diane Lane and Donald Sutherland in ''Fierce People,'' an offbeat, surprisingly dark coming-of-age movie that Griffin Dunne directed in the spring of 2004. Three and a half years later Mr. Yelchin, 18, is preparing to play his first grown-up -- as Pavel Chekov in J. J. Abrams's updating of ''Star Trek'' -- and ''Fierce People'' is finally headed for theaters, opening Friday in New York and Los Angeles under the new label of Autonomous Films, a sister company of Lionsgate.

docs.lead_paragraph: When F. Scott Fitzgerald remarked that the rich ''are different from you and me,'' he might have been thinking of someone like Ogden C. Osborne (Donald Sutherland), the reclusive, moody billionaire who casts a long shadow in Griffin Dunne's film ''Fierce People.'' With his blue-eyed, wide-as-the-sky stare, white beard and patriarchal rumble, Mr. Sutherland is the embodiment of a proud old aristocrat, slowly going to ruin, who knows too much about the dark side of human nature for his own comfort. He knows, for instance, that many if not most fortunes begin with crimes. That's why a thoughtful response to Fitzgerald's statement is not as simple as repeating Ernest Hemingway's disingenuous retort, ''Yes, they have more money.'' Great wealth confers power, and power changes people. Ogden presides like Louis XIV over his sprawling private kingdom of woods and fields in Vlyvalle, N.J. His wealth not only entitles him to do pretty much as he pleases but also exerts an irresistible force on everyone living within his radius. In ''Fierce People'' that force is like an invisible toxic gas with a seductively sweet scent that immobilizes people and poisons their souls.

docs.lead_paragraph: Experiencing the river used to mean day trips to the edge of the forest. Now there is a new breed of lodges that takes visitors right into the jungle, with an unprecedented level of comfort.

headline.main: Into the Amazon
headline.print_headline: Into the Amazon

docs.snippet: Experiencing the river used to mean day trips to the edge of the forest. Now there is a new breed of lodges that takes visitors right into the jungle, with an unprecedented level of comfort.

docs.lead_paragraph: WE were in a canoe tethered to a submerged tree, fishing for piranha in the dark waters of the Rio Negro, about 125 miles northwest of the Brazilian city of Manaus. It was late afternoon, and the sun was already beginning to set behind a fleecy thicket of clouds, tingeing them with hues of purple, pink and gold. Suddenly a dolphin surfaced less than 10 feet away, carved a graceful arc in the air and then disappeared into the water again. That night, back at the Anavilhanas Jungle Lodge, my base for that foray into the world's largest tropical rain forest, dinner -- which included onion soup with sweet potato chips, an Amazonian fish called dourado prepared in ginger sauce, beef tenderloin and coconut flan -- gave no hint of our rugged surroundings. Nor did the air-conditioned cottage where I slept, with its elegant tropical wood paneling and modern tiled bathroom. The next morning, I sought refuge from the overpowering heat and humidity in the lodge's swimming pool, where I watched boats of all shapes and sizes putt-putting their way up and down the river.

docs.lead_paragraph: Determined that dying languages not be lost forever, researchers are traveling the world to interview the last speakers. One language is lost about every two weeks, they say.

headline.main: Languages Die, but Not Their Last Words
headline.print_headline: Languages Die, but Not Their Last Words

docs.snippet: Determined that dying languages not be lost forever, researchers are traveling the world to interview the last speakers. One language is lost about every two weeks, they say.

docs.lead_paragraph: Of the estimated 7,000 languages spoken in the world today, linguists say, nearly half are in danger of extinction and likely to disappear in this century. In fact, one falls out of use about every two weeks. Some languages vanish in an instant, at the death of the sole surviving speaker. Others are lost gradually in bilingual cultures, as indigenous tongues are overwhelmed by the dominant language at school, in the marketplace and on television.

headline.main: Languages Die, but Not Their Last Words

docs.abstract: Study based on field research and data analysis supported by National Geographic Society and Living Tongues Institute for Endangered Languages finds five regions where languages are disappearing most rapidly--northern Australia, central South America, North America's upper Pacific coastal zone, eastern Siberia, Oklahoma, and southwestern United States; all areas have indigenous people, speaking diverse languages, in falling numbers; researchers say more than half the languages have no written form, leaving no dictionary, no text, no record of accumulated knowledge and history of vanished culture; photos (M)

keywords.value: American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: A WOMAN in a Chicago workplace caused quite a stir recently when she submitted her time sheet. She had worked 800 hours of overtime in 17 weeks, meaning she had been on the job about 12 or 13 hours a day, seven days a week, January through April. Because the woman, Carla Bird, is an assistant at Oprah Winfrey's production company, Harpo Studios, and because some seemingly jealous co-workers spread the word to the news media, her $32,000 payout was the talk of those who pay attention to workload for a living. The work/life experts were predictably appalled that Ms. Bird had logged so many hours.

headline.main: O.T. Isn't as Simple as Telling Time

docs.abstract: Rules that govern which employees can work for overtime and which employees are exempt are becoming blurred as work moves farther and farther out of office environment; some workers say that it is difficult to figure out when they are working verses not working within given day because so much work is done out of office and it overlaps with personal life; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AMAZON LUXURY To the Editor: Regarding ''Into the Amazon'' (Sept. 16): I was struck by the level of luxury and comfort offered by the resorts that have sprung up in the Amazon region. They are a far cry from the simple accommodations we had when, as a young boy, I lived with my parents at the edge of the Amazon jungle in Ecuador. But, as Larry Rohter mentions, ''luxury, of course, is a relative concept.'' Relative, in the sense that no amount of luxury will ever help me relive the amazing memories I have from those days, long before the new breed of lodges. But, to those who don't have such memories, go for it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon.com has been here before. In late 1999, Amazon's stock price vaulted into the triple digits, fueled by exuberance over the promise of e-commerce. But by 2001, slammed by the double whammy of a recession and the popping of the Internet bubble, the stock had collapsed back into the single digits.

headline.main: Amazon Says Profit Jumped In Quarter

docs.abstract: Amazon.com reports third-quarter profit of $80 million, threefold increase from $19 million it earned in same quarter of 2006; sales were $3.26 billion, up 41 percent from $2.31 billion in quarter last year; Amazon's stock gains 10 percent in advance of report and tops $100 for first time since December 1999, closing at $100.82; stock gives up most of those gains in after-hours trading, trading around $90; company's strong results can be partly explained by currency fluctuations and by 2.5 million copies of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows that Amazon sold; investors and analysts are also encouraged by more enduring trends, like migration of smaller retailers onto Amazon's network; graph (M)

headline.seo: Horror Films of the 1940s - Movies
headline.main: Joy of Fright: Old Chillers That Should Scare (but Not Terrorize) the Kids
headline.print_headline: Joy of Fright: Old Chillers That Should Scare (but Not Terrorize) the Kids

docs.snippet: Be afraid, kids, be very afraid (but not that afraid), with these old  chillers, whose terror is (mostly) off screen.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE natives pushed back as hard as they could, but slowly, terrifyingly, the huge door started to open. Then the giant ape burst through, sowing fear through Skull Island -- and the living room of my family's brownstone in Park Slope. I was all of 5, and I had stumbled on the original ''King Kong'' on television. I didn't switch it off. Instead I turned down the volume and hid behind the couch. Every time I peeked, things only got worse: Now Kong was chewing on a native like a toothpick; now he was squashing another into the mud with his giant foot.

headline.main: Joy of Fright: Old Chillers That Should Scare (but Not Terrorize) the Kids

docs.lead_paragraph: IN August, Comcast denied accusations that it was purposely disrupting file-sharing among its customers, but reports of stymied traffic -- particularly from people using the popular BitTorrent protocol -- have continued. Late last week, The Associated Press reported (news.yahoo.com) that Comcast ''actively interferes with attempts by some of its high-speed Internet subscribers to share files online.'' Peter Svensson of The A.P. wrote that the practice was ''the most drastic example yet of data discrimination by a U.S. Internet service provider.''

headline.main: Sharing Is Never Easy

docs.abstract: What's Online column; Associated Press reported on news.yahoo.com that Comcast Corp actively interferes with attempts by some of its high-speed Internet subscribers top share files online; Peter Svensson wrote that practice was most drastic example yet of data discrimination by US Internet service provider; Comcast told Brad Stone of New York Times that it does not block access to any applications, but it does use latest technologies to manage its network to ensure quality of its customers; anonymous Comcast executive admits that in some cases peer-to-peer file-sharing traffic like that generated by BitTorrent is delayed, though not blocked; DSL Prime editor Dave Burstein is among those not persuaded; blog VentureBeat has been following venture capitalists scrounging for alternatives to technology investments as free-falling costs have drastically cut need for outside financing; Eric Eldon notes Kleiner Perkins took part in $50 million investment in YesPPG, shirt factory in Shanghai; 'Felice,' stay-at-home mother whose husband earns $5,000 to $6,000 per month, describes her extravagant spending practices on Oprah Winfrey Show Web site, while her children go without health insurance; says she sells her children's toys to generate some income; drawing (L)

headline.main: Early-Music Maestro’s Juilliard Plans
headline.print_headline: Early-Music Maestro’s Juilliard Plans

docs.snippet: Next spring William Christie will establish a series of residencies, if not quite a home, at the Juilliard School.

docs.lead_paragraph: For early-music lovers in New York City, William Christie has long been the big one who got away. He hails, after all, from Buffalo. While New York has had to content itself with modest and sporadic efforts that tend to get lost in the big-city shuffle -- even when presented as a festival, like the current New York Early Music Celebration, which continues, little noticed, until mid-November -- Mr. Christie has been turning Paris on its ear for 28 years with performances of Baroque and early Classical music by his crack ensemble, Les Arts Florissants. Happily, the rest of the world has been able to tune in too, through the group's recordings and tours, including periodic visits to New York.

headline.main: Early-Music Maestro's Juilliard Plans

docs.abstract: William Christie, conductor of early music whose ensemble Les Arts Florissants resides in Paris, will return to New York City to take up residency at Julliard; will offer workshop at school, which for first time is offering graduate program in historical performance; says if residency is successful, it will be prelude to long-term connection with school; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lynda Carter, who made her New York cabaret debut on Tuesday, took on Johnny Mercer and Harold Arlen’s hydra-headed “Blues in the Night” and wrested it to the ground.

headline.main: Great Hera! Amazon Trades Her Lasso for Stage Mike
headline.print_headline: Great Hera! Amazon Trades Her Lasso for Stage Mike

docs.snippet: Lynda Carter, who made her New York cabaret debut on Tuesday, took on Johnny Mercer and Harold Arlen’s hydra-headed “Blues in the Night” and wrested it to the ground.

docs.lead_paragraph: As befits the singer best known for playing Wonder Woman, the larger the song, the more lived-in the performance. For Lynda Carter, who made her New York cabaret debut on Tuesday evening at Feinstein's at Loews Regency, that meant taking on Johnny Mercer and Harold Arlen's hydra-headed ''Blues in the Night'' and wrestling it to the ground. When she was growing up in Arizona, Ms. Carter said, her mother, who loved country, blues, jazz and calypso, used to wag her finger at her and sing this epic blues lament, which begins with ''My mama done tol' me.'' Ms. Carter infused this desolate howl of a rejected lover who has lost faith in the opposite sex with a sense of affirmation. Isn't a superhero's responsibility to restore people's faith that everything's going to be all right?

docs.lead_paragraph: Fogy design comes out of the woodwork.

headline.main: Club House
headline.print_headline: Club House

docs.snippet: Fogy design comes out of the woodwork.

docs.lead_paragraph: If William Randolph Hearst were to come back from the grave, he would surely feel vindicated for his extravagant sense of design. Hearst Castle, the 97,000-square-foot pad in San Simeon, Calif., that he built from 1919 to 1947 in a pastiche of grandiose architectural flourishes, was decorated with truckloads of European art, Italian and Spanish ceilings, enough rugs to fill a bazaar, and an original Roman temple front. Now his baronial-manorial aesthetic is having a second coming -- albeit in a slightly more accessible way. These days, no party is complete without ornamental woodwork, heavy velvet curtains and tapestries, mosaic tiling, tasseled sofas and ottomans, a stuffed creature or 12, and plenty of ''patina'' on the floor -- the better to absorb spilled cocktails and other party effluvia.

headline.main: Club House

docs.abstract: Trend in interior design for wealthy is toward ornamental woodwork, heavy velvet curtains and tapestries to create eclectic environment mimicking extravagances found in mansions of days gone by; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Fogy design comes out of the woodwork.

docs.lead_paragraph: WITHOUT quite having a clear plan, Gregg Rottler began contemplating his Web empire last year on his desktop computer at his home near Tampa, Fla. As many bloggers have done, Mr. Rottler, a state environmental code officer, followed an impulse to share stories about annoyances. He and his wife, Karen, an elementary school teacher, often eat out, and he realized that people liked to talk about restaurant experiences gone wrong. ''I've had my share of bad dinners, and I thought this could provide some catharsis and also be a source of entertainment,'' he said. ''I always wondered how people put those Web sites together. So I bought a humongous manual and worked through it'' to learn how to create a site about bad restaurant experiences.

headline.main: Venting, Yes. Profiting, No.

docs.lead_paragraph: KENNY TIMMONS has spent three long weekends in New York City since 2003, catching up with friends he knew in Ireland, visiting ground zero, restocking his wardrobe at Armani and Niketown and chatting about real estate with a bartender in an Irish pub in Midtown Manhattan. That was enough of a glimpse of New York for Mr. Timmons, a 32-year-old carpenter from County Meath, Ireland. Last summer, he put down 10 percent on a $760,000 studio under construction at 75 Wall Street.

docs.lead_paragraph: When it comes to food, the spirit of adventure would seem to be inherent, not acquired. Some people are simply more game than others, sampling tripe, silkworm pupae and a cobra's gallbladder, not to mention small, cuddly mammals that back home might have been christened Snowball or Sparky. (Are these the same people whose idea of fun is bungee jumping?) Recent research suggests that fearlessness is ordained by a gene. I'm quite sure I don't have it. Tom Parker Bowles does. (Let's just get this out of the way: he's Camilla's son.) Or rather, he'd like to have it. ''The Year of Eating Dangerously: A Global Adventure in Search of Culinary Extremes'' chronicles his travels to destinations near (Gloucestershire) and far (Nashville, Seoul, Beijing) in an attempt to acquire new experiences and eat like the natives do, and ultimately what makes it so engaging is that he only partly succeeds. He's fascinated by revulsion -- his own and other people's. ''More often than not,'' he tells us in the introduction, ''it was the idea of the insect, dog or snake that put me off. It was my brain shutting down before I had the chance to reason.'' And yet, the reader can't help thinking as she follows him to the Fiery Foods Show in New Mexico (which a woman running a local chili store calls ''the culinary equivalent of running with the bulls'') that it's the idea of eating these things and not the things themselves that appeals to him. Or, more precisely, the idea of having eaten them, since in most instances he's trying not to think about what it is he's forcing down. With the single-mindedness of a champion athlete, he manages on more than one occasion to override the gag reflex, but the rest of the time he's retching, sweating, clinging to the bar or, worse, bolting. The feat requires prodigious amounts of alcohol for steeling the nerves, but then that makes for hangovers and a queasy stomach, which tend to curtail his hunger and dampen his resolve.

headline.main: Reading About Eating

docs.abstract: Roundup of books about food and eating, including The Year of Eating Dangerously: A Global Adventure in Search of Culinary Extremes by Tom Parker Bowles, The Tenth Muse: My Life in Food by Judith Jones and My Life in France by Julia Child with Alex Prud'homme; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: ONLINE retailers take solace in knowing that no matter how painful it may be to click around endlessly searching for products, it still often beats the mall. Now online merchants are introducing search features meant to take even more pain out of the shopping experience. The changes range from subtle to radical, but in a holiday retailing environment that looks like a nail-biter, businesses are pinning high hopes on such initiatives.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE microfinance industry -- bankers to the poor -- faces a paradox of scale, growing large in some ways but remaining small in others. There are more than 3,100 microfinance institutions worldwide, serving 113 million poor people. But even thriving microfinanciers are tiny by banking business standards. They typically make loans of $100 or so to entrepreneurs living on a dollar or two a day.

docs.lead_paragraph: AS one of Silicon Valley's most respected entrepreneurs, Marc Andreessen is something of a connoisseur of what he calls ''productivity porn,'' or techniques to maximize personal productivity. But in recent months, Mr. Andreessen -- a founder of Netscape Communications and more recently Ning, which allows users to create their own social networks -- has become enthralled with an unlikely purveyor: Timothy Ferriss, a boyish first-time motivational author from Long Island whose curriculum vitae includes stints as a competitive kickboxer and tango champion.

docs.lead_paragraph: What is the origin of road movies? A year ago, I interviewed Wim Wenders on this topic for a documentary about ''On the Road,'' Jack Kerouac and the legacy of the Beat generation. For me, the first documentary filmmakers, like Robert Flaherty, the creator of the landmark 1922 film ''Nanook of the North,'' were the founding fathers of this narrative form. Jorge Luis Borges once said that what interested him in literature was naming what had not yet been named. The early documentary pioneers did exactly that. A movie like ''Nanook'' or ''Song of Ceylon,'' Basil Wright's 1934 classic about life in what is now Sri Lanka, depicted a human and physical geography that had not been captured before in moving images.

headline.main: Trend Spotting | Liner Notes

docs.snippet: Several high-end cruise lines are sending some of their poshest boats to exotic destinations.

docs.lead_paragraph: Cruising less-traveled waters used to mean ''rustic'' cabins and close quarters. Now several high-end cruise lines are sending some of their poshest boats to exotic destinations. This January, Aqua Expeditions will launch the 12-suite M/V Aqua, which will sail the Peruvian Amazon year-round and serve nouveau Andean dishes courtesy of the Lima chef Pedro Miguel Schiaffino (www.aquaexpeditions.com; $1,950 to $4,550 per person). In Russia, the 58-cabin Volga Dream -- decked out in mahogany and etched glass -- sets sail on the Volga from Moscow to St. Petersburg (May through September; 800-633-1008; www.exeterinternational.com; from $6,700 per person). And come spring, Silversea, the company that stocks its ships with goods from Loro Piana and Acqua di Parma, will make stops in Iran; the Silver Cloud is set to dock in Bandar Abbas on its Dubai to Dubai cruise (800-722-9955; www.silversea.com; from $2,937 per person).

docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon.com introduced its electronic book reader today at a packed event in New York. Unlike other products in this area, Amazon's $399 Kindle is designed to be used without ever connecting to a computer. Instead it has a wireless Internet connection that lets users browse Amazon's online store on the device and download a book in less than a minute.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Kindle, Amazon's electronic book reader and online service, represents a major commitment by its chief executive, Jeff Bezos, above, to help shape the future of books. So it stands to reason that there will be both software upgrades and new versions of the device. That makes it fun to speculate about what's coming next. Here are some guesses: LARGER SCREENS, WITH COLOR When the Kindle's electronic ink technology improves, the screen may also, opening the device to books with lavish illustrations and color photos. Since one of Kindle's selling points is its ability to display magazines and newspapers, color would seem to be a must-have feature.

headline.main: Small Merchants Gain Large Presence on Web
headline.print_headline: Small Merchants Gain Large Presence on Web

docs.snippet: Mom-and-pop retailers have helplessly stood by as big-box merchants steamrolled over them. Online, though, they are not going down without a fight.

docs.lead_paragraph: MOM-AND-POP retailers have helplessly stood by over the last decade as big-box merchants steamrolled over them. Online, though, small merchants are not going down without a fight. The number of small- and medium-size retailers selling online has swelled in the last two years, from 21 percent to 32 percent, according to a survey by IDC, a consulting firm. Aided by less expensive and more sophisticated technology, stores like RealmDekor.com, CleanAirGardening.com and SitStay.com are competing with retailers as well as bigger sites like Amazon.

headline.main: Small Merchants Gain Large Presence on Web

docs.abstract: IDC says number of small- and medium-size retailers selling online has risen in last two years, from 21 percent to 32 percent; aided by less expensive and more sophisticated technology, stores like RealmDekor.com, CleanAirGardening.com and SitStay.com are competing with retailers as well as bigger sites like Amazon; these businesses lack huge marketing budgets of their bigger peers, but they are unearthing cheap advertising methods that, in some cases, help them compete with million-dollar promotions; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: -- most people have -- she knows her way around a rip-roaring read. The complaint in her $100 million civil suit against the News Corporation, with its riveting passages about corporate connivance, public malfeasance and ill-fated romance, is as much a page-turner as any of the dozens of salacious best sellers she produced at ReganBooks, her imprint at HarperCollins before she was fired at the end of last year. But the deeper I went in the complaint, the more I felt I had read this book before. The narrative -- about a talented but unpredictable impresario who joined forces with a media company with a great deal of fanfare before a huge, ugly divorce -- mirrored the confrontation between Rosie O'Donnell and Gruner & Jahr USA in 2002. The parallels are not exact -- it was Gruner & Jahr that sued Ms. O'Donnell on the grounds of breach of contract, while Ms. Regan is the one doing the suing, claiming that she had been defamed by News Corporation officials -- but they are instructive, especially for the News Corporation.

You might never have found yourself thinking, You know, this book doesn't have enough buttons. docs.lead_paragraph: No contemporary poet is famous, but some are less unfamous than others. That's because the poetry world, like most areas of American life, has its own peculiar celebrity system -- and if the rewards of that system rarely involve gift suites filled with swag from Jean Patou, they remain tempting enough to keep grown writers hustling. The problem is, poetic stardom is an unpredictable business. Good writing doesn't guarantee a reputation; bad writing doesn't guarantee oblivion; nor can grace, money or nimble careerism entirely explain why Poet X reads to overflowing auditoriums, whereas Poet Y reads to his cats. Maybe it's simply the case that, as William Munny remarked in ''Unforgiven,'' ''deserve's got nothing to do with it.'' Which brings us to Michael O'Brien, whose new collection, SLEEPING AND WAKING(Flood Editions, paper, $12.95), makes one wish the laws of poetic celebrity were less chaotic. O'Brien, born in 1939, began his career as a participant in the Eventorium, a coterie of New York artists with a surrealist bent. Unlike other groups with more ambition (or better promotional skills), this collective never became a major feature in the landscape of contemporary American poetry, and O'Brien's early work is now extremely difficult to find. Not that it's easy to get your hands on his more recent writing. Aside from the present volume, none of O'Brien's individual collections are still in print. His 1986 book ''The Ruin,'' an assortment of translations, is currently being sold on eBay by a book trader who claims to have ''the only copy on the Web!'' An excellent selected poems, ''Sills,'' was published in 2000, but so few copies are available that one recently listed for $35 on Amazon Marketplace. As a writer, O'Brien seems to have opted for solitary dedication; unfortunately, admirable though it is, that choice may have made him invisible even to those who are looking for him.

docs.lead_paragraph: NEWSPAPER publishers and other content producers have a complicated relationship with giant search engines like Google and Yahoo. They simultaneously try to curry favor with these sites, hiring people known as optimizers with magical incantations to make articles show up high on the results pages and drive traffic, all the while grumbling that maybe, perhaps, it isn't fair for the search engines to make copies of their material -- so that it can be searched or appear on aggregation sites like Google News -- without compensation. But few are willing to speak as unambiguously as Samuel Zell, the real estate developer who intends to buy the Tribune Company, did this spring at Stanford University.

docs.lead_paragraph: TiVo may be getting a second chance by thinking outside the box that made it famous in the first place. As the company that popularized digital video recorders, TiVo turned time-shifted, commercial-skipping television watching into a verb, only to antagonize the television industry and see cheaper, more generic DVRs undercut its success. Now it is trying to climb into the black by working with the media companies it once threatened and moving away from the hardware that it pioneered.

headline.main: TiVo Shifts to Help Companies It Once Threatened

docs.abstract: TiVo, which popularized digital video recorders that skipped televised commercials, is trying to climb into black by working with media companies it once threatened and moving away from hardware that it pioneered; TiVo recently received patent approval on time-warp technology that lets users record one program while watching another; recently announced partnerships with NBC Universal and media-buying agency Carat to provide second-by-second viewership data and demographic ratings information collected from sample of 20,000 TiVo subscribers; those deals underscore TiVo's new emphasis on subscriptions and media services rather than hardware; TiVo is helping networks and advertisers overcome its technology that fast-forwarded past commercials by offering interactive banner ads that make sponsors' names visible as their ads are being fast-forwarded; Tivo will also start carrying out contracts with Comcast and Cox; those deals will allow cable subscribers to pay premium to download TiVo software onto their generic DVRs, wich will give them access to TiVo's interface without requiring them to buy any more equipment; TiVo chief executive Tom Rogers comments; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: SHORTLY after Radiohead released its album ''In Rainbows'' online in October, the band misplaced its password for Max/MSP, a geek-oriented music software package that the guitarist Jonny Greenwood uses constantly. It wasn't the first time it had happened, Mr. Greenwood said over a cup of tea at the venerable Randolph Hotel here. As usual Radiohead contacted Max/MSP's developers, Cycling '74, for another password. ''They wrote back,'' Mr. Greenwood said, '''Why don't you pay us what you think it's worth?'''

docs.lead_paragraph: The police jail at Abaetetuba could not be torn down soon enough for Márcia Soares, a lawyer and federal human rights official here. To her, the jail has come to symbolize everything that is wrong with Brazil's efforts to safeguard women and children from violence. It was at Abaetetuba, in the northeastern state of Para on the fringes of the Amazon, that a 15-year-old girl arrested on suspicion of petty theft was illegally placed among 34 male inmates in late October. For 26 days they treated her as their plaything, raping and torturing her repeatedly. Sometimes she traded sex for food; other times, she was simply raped, federal investigators here said.

headline.main: Rape of Girl, 15, Exposes Abuses in Brazil Prison System

docs.abstract: Rape and torture of 15-year-old girl who was arrested on suspicion of petty theft and illegally placed among male inmates in police jail at Abaetetuba, Brazil, has come to symbolize failure of Brazil's efforts to safeguard women and minors in country's overcrowded prison system; federal investigators say police, judge, public defender and many other people were negligent or actually complicit in case, which is causing soul-searching among federal officials; women make up only 5 percent of Brazil's prison population, but number is growing, and states have not built enough jails and prisons with separate facilities for women, though they are required to so do by law; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BUYING a book online is easy, but buying electronics can be intimidating. Is it a good gift? Are you getting the right model? Are you getting a good deal, or getting taken? The bad news is there is no one-stop shop for consumer electronics. You will need to do your research on one site, your bargain hunting elsewhere and your self-reassurance at a third location. Unless you are already familiar with under-the-hood components, the big gadget blogs like Engadget.com and Gizmodo.com are not much help. Their insider's advice is buried among posts like ''Displaytech FLCOS microdisplays to be used in embeddable pico-projectors.''

docs.lead_paragraph: A book of fairy tales handwritten and illustrated by J. K. Rowling sold for nearly $4 million at Sotheby's auction house in London on Thursday. One day later, the identity of the winning bidder was revealed: Amazon.com. The company now owns one of seven copies of ''The Tales of Beedle the Bard,'' which is hand-bound in leather with silver mounts, The Associated Press reported. Proceeds from the sale will benefit the Children's Voice, an organization that campaigns for children's rights in Europe founded in 2005 by Ms. Rowling and Baroness Nicholson, a member of Britain's House of Lords. Amazon has posted photographs of the book and says it will review the tales on its site. The company has also created a discussion board to answer questions about the book's contents. Craig Berman, a spokesman for Amazon, said the company plans to put the book on a tour of libraries and schools. Ms. Rowling wrote the Beedle tales after finishing the Harry Potter series. She said the other six copies of the book had been given to people who were closely connected to the creation of the series.

docs.lead_paragraph: CLACK, clack, clack. That's the sound of fingers tapping, as holiday shoppers forsake their Excel spreadsheets and arid texts for the heady allure of the Web. Judging by holiday purchases, online buying sprees are turning even the most solemn of sobersides into saucer-eyed children mesmerized by glitter and gilt. At the height of the gift-giving season, their aggregate taste for diamond-drop earrings, sequin slippers, dome-shape rings, and gold-plated cameras, has given a vigorous push to luxury sales on the Internet. Indeed, from late November through mid-December, a time when conventional retailing has been sluggish at best, e-commerce is flourishing, with spending ahead by 30 percent over the same period last year, according to a study by MasterCard Advisors. The company reported an increase of 10.8 percent in luxury purchases.

headline.main: The Online Gold Standard

docs.lead_paragraph: During my first few weeks in New York, the most striking surprise was that my New York friends, when emerging from the subway, always knew which direction was downtown. As if possessing the magnetic receptors of migratory birds, they'd stalk off in the correct direction without even a momentary pause at the top of the entrance stairs. This, it seemed to me, was the cultural inheritance of the native New Yorker.

docs.lead_paragraph: HERE is a formative moment from the life of a writer, at the long ago age of 5. It is Christmas. There is a fir hung with metallic icicles, a fleecy ''snow'' blanket wrapped around its base. On the fake snow blanket are piled many shiny boxes, and several of them are his. The particular box he remembers is wrapped in crinkly paper and has his name written on it inside a snowflake-shaped tag. Contained in the box, as he will soon learn, is a portable record player and a small selection of 45-r.p.m. discs -- objects that would no doubt be found deeply mysterious by those too young to have contemplated the payout on a 401(k).

docs.lead_paragraph: Apple's sputtering efforts to be a major purveyor of video downloads may get a boost in 2008 from an agreement with 20th Century Fox for digital movie rentals. Apple has been trying to interest a number of Hollywood studios in an iTunes rental service, and several people familiar with the negotiations said that more than one studio would appear onstage at the company's MacWorld exhibition here beginning Jan. 14 to endorse a new Apple movie rental service.

headline.main: Apple Making Deals for Web Video Rentals

docs.abstract: Apple's sputtering efforts to be major purveyor of video downloads may get boost in 2008 from agreement with 20th Century Fox for digital movie rentals; Apple has been trying to interest number of Hollywood studios in iTunes rental service; Apple and Fox decline comment on agreement (M)
docs.snippet: Apple’s sputtering efforts to be a major purveyor of video downloads may get a boost in 2008 from an agreement with 20th Century Fox for digital movie rentals.

docs.lead_paragraph: COUPON lovers, take heart. The era of waiting, scissors in hand, for the Sunday newspaper circular is over. On Jan. 3, Valassis Communications, which distributes paper coupons for products like Eggo waffles and Dr Pepper cola, will take a giant leap onto the Internet by introducing a portal for coupons called RedPlum.com. Until now, Valassis had distributed coupons primarily through newspaper inserts and snail mail envelopes.

headline.main: Shifting Coupons, From Clip and Save to Point and Click

docs.abstract: Valassis Communications, distributor of paper coupons, on Jan 3 will introduce portal for coupons called RedPlum.com; will focus on promoting RedPlum brand, using its traditional paper circulars to direct people to Web site; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart said it had ended the business because Hewlett-Packard, a chief technology partner, had decided to discontinue essential infrastructure for the service.

headline.main: Wal-Mart Pulls Plug on Movies via the Web
